headline: Salesforce
pros: Great company spirit with a lot of great people.  Very successful.
cons: Work life balance can be hard.  If you don't like ongoing change, it is not the company for you :)

headline: Account Executive
pros: This is a company that is driven by the success of their customers. I feel this is certainly replicated through to employees and everything is set up for you to be successful in your career. The commitment to making you the best you can be is phenomenal and the amount resource they provide to make sure you're succeeding is second to none. It is extremely fast paced, what else would you expect from such an innovative company, one of the many reasons I love Salesforce.
cons: It is a fast growing, large company with a complex org structure. Navigating the right teams and people takes time, but everyone is willing to help you.

headline: Will drain you dry
pros: It's a fast paced culture.
cons: Extremely short staffed, meaning workload is immense and the metrics pressure is insanely stupid putting undeserved pressure on employees.  Upper management is completely clueless about anything that doesn't appear on their dashboard.

headline: Decent
pros: Good place to start your career
cons: Politics, politics, politics, politics, politics

headline: Project Manager
pros: Great, supportive culture that values work/life balance, and working remotely. Values transparency and employee feedback. Always innovating and looking toward the future
cons: As the company grows its sometimes harder to navigate the different teams whose efforts may overlap. Priorities are constantly shifting-you need to be agile and not afraid of change.

headline: It's a SaaS company with a lot of complexity.
pros: Lots of mobility and challenges. Work/Life balance is what you want it to be. Plenty of opportunities for interacting with coworkers outside of work.
cons: Different "clouds" have different code bases and cultures, and some of them aren't as interested in modern development methodology, or even being able to do basic code analysis.

headline: Great company for anyone wanting to learn how to market technology from the highest caliber brand-builders.
pros: Marc Benioff is an amazing visionary. Great culture and interesting work. Incredible opportunity to learn from customers through close interactions with the field, directly, and a series of customer research functions.
cons: Limited growth opportunities and a lot of churn projects you might not find satisfaction in. Less strategy, more art and logistics (due to heavy event and presentation focus). Highly matrixed causing sometimes needless delays and pivots.

headline: Great work life balance
pros: Great benefits. 1-1-1 philanthropic model. Great people. Really interesting problems to work on. Lots of opportunity for growth.
cons: Miss out on a good chunk of culture/events by working in satellite office (although you can always participate online).

headline: A Great Culture of Inclusivity
pros:
Salesforce is an amazing company! It has a strong and inclusive culture as well as great people. It offers lots of opportunities for career growth and defining your own path as well as very good salary.
Lots of learning opportunities. I joined as an experience architect but without experience of Salesforce. My first 90 Days at the company were an educational ramp program designed to immerse me in all the offerings of Salesforce. Really helped me to get up to speed. And the learning opportunities didn't stop after my 90 Day Ramp, Trailhead is a key part of the Salesforce learning system which is always available.
cons: Salesforce is a rapidly growing company and sometimes it can be hard to find the right people to talk too. But the internal social network helps a lot.

headline: SF Review
pros:
Ohana Culture
Friendly People
Everyone loves their job/ works hars
cons:
Lack of diversity
Women in Leadership

headline: Best choice for your career
pros: Mentoring, sales skills, Wonderfull product, great energy, innovation
cons: Bigger and bigger, far from city center

headline: Amazing
pros: Absolutely amazing company to work for. Great culture and benefits.
cons: Not much to be unhappy about.

headline: Great company
pros: Salesforce is a fantastic organization.  Its the top employer in the space offering amazing benefits, career growth opportunities, and strong culture. I would recommend the organization as a great place to work.
cons: There seems to be a lack of career progression opportunities for those employees who are remote or not willing to move to HQ.  This is understandable but limiting none the less.

headline: Innovation and Client Success
pros: Salesforce is truly delivers on innovation and companies drive significant impact with the platform.  In sales, refreshing to have confidence in product and ability to makes a significant difference in those you serve.
cons: Company has grown fast and they have not quite figured out how to enable and ensure the culture expands to remote EE's through leadership/

headline: There is a lot of show going on and poor middle managers
pros:
- Flexible with working remotely
- Good pay and benefits
- Flexible work hours as long as you do your job 
- Great culture in the engineering department
cons:
- Majority don't truly care
- Too much emphasis on process that it becomes an overhead for those who want to get the job done
- No sense of loyalty or mechanism in place for career development, you are on your own
- A lot of it is show business
- very poor management

headline: Great company to work!
pros:
- Leadership
- Team
- Innovation
- Culture
- Caring about community
cons: - Speed to deliver can be improved

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Lots of perks and secure job stability.
cons: They do not hire within and at times do not provide the gratitude deserved by employees for over achieving.

headline: Great company to work!
pros:
- Leadership
- Team
- Innovation
- Culture
- Caring about community
cons: - Speed to deliver can be improved

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Lots of perks and secure job stability.
cons: They do not hire within and at times do not provide the gratitude deserved by employees for over achieving.

headline: Business Development Representative Apprentice
pros: Awesome work environment, great benefits, unlimited opportunities to grow within the company, location flexibility, managers are well trained and extremely knowledgable
cons: Not too many cons... Apprentice don't have access to all of the benefits since we're part time (this is normal). Relative to geographic location, pay is pretty low for apprentice so living in the city can be tight money wise.

headline: Sales manager
pros: Managing director is honest and open, employees are nice
cons: Working hoursare not very sociable

headline: Account Executive
pros: Really care about their employees, get to work with great companies, are able to be more than just a sales person because of their focus on customer success and multiple product lines
cons: hard grind and a lot of pressure

headline: Great company
pros:
innovation
work life balance
volunteer time off
cons:
stagnant compensation
small raises and promotions

headline: Sales Development Rep
pros:
- Great product that's easy to talk about. 
- Tons of inbound leads. 
- Really fun floor culture.
- Lots of training; it's a developmental role. 
- High on target earning. 
- Work life balance
cons:
- Not performance based. Top performer gets treated and paid the same as lowest. 
- No commission or bonus based on performance. 
- Slow progression to next role for quick learners. 
- Lack of diversity on floor. 
- Major issues with complacency/laziness across department.

headline: #Dreamjob
pros:
- Really smart people
- All put in lots of effort to get stuff done
- You are given almost everything you need to succeed in your role
- Onboarding is amazing. 
- I have a team environment , that is supportive. 
- I have an amazing manager, who leads and supports her team. 
- IT Systems are amazing. 
- Concierge is amazing. 
- I feel like the management structure is flat / welcoming. 
- CEO speaks out on things that he believes in publicly - Equality, Fair pay etc 
- Parker Harris leads by example.. when NA24 went down.. his internal briefing was amazing.. and made me proud to join Salesforce.
cons:
- I think there maybe too many Oracle people coming across that may eventually lead to a change in culture, make sure we only take the culture fit ones :)
- Salesforce markets to the customer so well... sets the vision and goes on executing it.. there should be a communication strategy laid better to inform and communicate this to front line staff. 
- I think in some roles ( not my own ) aren't given the opportunity to expand on what they are doing they are placed in a box and have to wait their time to get some flexibility in what they can do / given a runway or roadmap ( this is just an observation on certain teams, this is not the case in my case ) so this maybe ill-informed.

headline: A literal High School
pros: Great benefits, smart people, cool product. The company tries to keep that start-up feel and tries it's best to take care of it's employees. Salesforce also has a great volunteering program. Everything is team based.
cons:
Salesforce is a combination of Game of Thrones and House of Cards in a corporate environment. The politics in this company are extremely embraced by it's culture. Everyone has an opinion of you and everyone else. Work feels like an actual theatrical performance- making sure your interpersonal interactions are precisely how they need to be. Everyone has an opinion on something and if people don't take a liking to you right away- prepare to be isolated. Managers are so far up their own butts that they play even more into the politics game. At Salesforce it's next to impossible to be yourself- specially if you are a little bit different. People are willing to sabotage if it means that they themselves can progress. 

It's not a healthy environment to work in. Specially when people are still in a high school state of mind.  You better be ready to play the game if you are ever going to advance in this company.

headline: CFL is behind the times
pros: salesforce is an amazing company, innovative and inspiring, CEO is great, fantastic product, great sales team
cons: The CFL department (Support, Services, Customer Success) is old school thinking. The opposite of the products team, CFL is not innovative and is extremely political. It's all about who you know and has little to do with creative thought and accomplishments.

headline: Oracle wannabe - stay away!!!
pros:
- Nice offices
- Competitive pay/benefits
- Flexibility
- Good Brand from the outside.
- leading enterprise products.
cons:
- Completely focuses on sales, nothing else. All that matters to them is hitting quarterly numbers.
- High Churn of people due to lack of training, management and high pressured cooker demanding instant results.
- Poor leadership in place - often people who have done well put into management positions with no exp or people skills. 
- Zero career development and growth. 
- No culture - you will just be another number.
- Many people unresponsive and hiding.
- Very political and packed with egos. 
- management seem to ignore and look down on more junior employees as beneath them. 
- Poor communication to employees.

headline: Sales Development Representative - Middle East
pros: Amazing company culture and continuous innovation in Emerging Markets - we are at the forefront of CRM development.
cons: nothing in here at all

headline: Salesforce cares
pros: You get all the help needed for your career at Salesforce, this includes mentoring but also personal wellness.
cons: We are growing so fast that the company feels like it is changing quickly.

headline: Loving the Ohana culture here in Salesforce!
pros: A year back, I decided to join Salesforce after reading the feedback on Glassdoor and it was one of the best decision I have made. This is a great company with everyone in office treating each other like family. The company provides good benefits and welfare and the management truly believe that it's the people that makes a company great.
cons: It's a fast pace work environment and change is the only constant here in Salesforce. With this dynamic environment brings stress and the pressure to perform as everyone is putting their best forward.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Culture, Management style, Customers, location. opportunity to learn most relevant industry practices. Chance to work with really great folks.
cons: Takes a while  to find your footing. Certification process may be intimidating for some, takes a while to onboard.

headline: Sales
pros: Amazing culture, many smart people to learn from, progression and career development guaranteed!
cons: No cons at all!!! maybe only Dublin :-)

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
- Working with a great team of people who are very capable, very driven and good fun and that makes for a really great work environment! 
- Salary is good and career development opportunities are very encouraging. 
- The benefits are also great with a quarterly wellness allowance :) and there are top performer prizes on offer also .. the next being a trip to Prague for our department. 
- You also get paid to do 56 hours of volunteer work!
cons: - It is a target driven organization so if you're not competitive, you might find it daunting, but if you're into that, you get a real great buzz from it.

headline: Account Executive
pros: An amazing company with great people and endless career growth opportunities as well as very good salary.
cons: High pressure environment. 1 month at Salesforce equals 6 months elsewhere. We have monthly targets which you DO NOT miss.

headline: Senior manager
pros:
- challenging work
- very nice coworkers
- Dreamforce!
cons:
- Hard to keep up-
- Feel like you're constantly criticized and failing

headline: Engineer
pros:
-Free food

-Free Caltrain Pass

-Nice hardwares

-Good office location, next to Palo Alto caltrain.
cons:
Unless you are single and have a lot of free time, I recommend you look elsewhere for jobs.

-Team got so large in 2016, what used to be a friendly culture becomes more of less corporate like.

-Ex-CEO left, the whole RelateIQ CRM product is getting killed out at some points.

-Constantly pivot with fears one day the product is not competitive.

-The motto is people, idea, moment and RESULT, yes, result is the only they care regardless of how we achieve it.

-Some of the management here are very junior and got converted from early day RelateIQ engineers. With a mindset of moving fast and ridiculously unorganized, this put a whole lot of work on engineers. A lot of LEGACY code that got produced without being thoughtfully planned out. This leads to a lot of hard to trace bugs.

-A lot of PM here are super junior who have no clue what's the product development is. This leads to product decision delay, etc. Product planning is totally a joke here. No Scrum of any sort, the process puts a lot of weight on engineer to figure out the problems and solutions. The only thing the PM really does here is to send out email releases when something is about to release.

-Lots of young engineers who only care about deliver cool features fast which sacrifices the quality. If you happen to work on a feature last, you are the single point of contact and have to maintain the whole load of it.

-Watch out for all the good perks, at some points, when SalesforceIQ is fully melted into Salesforce family, these perks will also go away. Take a look at the Fraiche account, the Lyft credit, the housing stipend, they are all gone.

-Don't let the offer congratz email blast from the recruiting and engineering team cloud your judgement. All the things about the family like culture and what's not, this culture is no longer respected. 

-Some middle managers are control freaks who like to micro manage every of you move.

-Every Friday demo is just a hacky thing that squeezes out your extra work and you feel obligated to demo something to the company.

-The quarterly Hackday mentality is just another way you work extra hard and late night to produce something really cool.

pros:
- challenging work
- very nice coworkers
- Dreamforce!
cons:
- Hard to keep up-
- Feel like you're constantly criticized and failing
