headline: Grpwth
pros: The company is on a fast growth path which provides opportunities for new employees. There are opportunities to try new things which the company indulges with a high tolerance for mistakes as long as they are quickly corrected.
cons: The downside of a growth company is a lack of clear process which can cause setbacks when trying to do your job well. You need to have a very flexible approach to working.

headline: Internship Experience
pros: Great perks and culture, internship program is one of the best for SF interns
cons: Work can be a bit dry, hard to network due to many employees

headline: Account Executive
pros: A few of the things I enjoyed most about working at Salesforce: great people, great benefits, lots of opportunity for career advancement, numerous ways the company gives back to the community.
cons: A few of the things I enjoyed least about working at Salesforce: doesn't pay that well, high pressure environment to succeed, very political and you're forced to play the game.

headline: Senior Manager Revenue Accounting
pros: Culture, community, stability, flexible work hours, good benefits
cons: Lack of clarity for promotion

headline: Senior Release Engineer
pros: Lot of new opportunities to work
cons: nothing that I can think of

headline: Great On-boarding Experience
pros: it's been an amazing on-boarding experience.  The collaboration internally between my teammates helping me get answers to my questions feels great.  The training I've been afforded as a new employee is extremely rich.
cons: there is a considerable amount of pressure on the monthly sales cadence even though you have a annual quota.

headline: What you have heard is true
pros: Salesforce is a cut above. The employee engagement is off the charts. The focus on quality products to help customers is feverish. They reward great work and after 6 months here my near 2 decades at SAP and Oracle seem a little like wasted energy. I have had more fun at Salesforce than ever before and I love the people I work with.
cons: Having been around, none of the challenges at Salesforce seem insurmountable.

headline: Lead Solution Consultant
pros:
Lots of products to sell
OT for Commercial Solution Engineers
ESPP
cons:
Political - Have to manage up
Managers make or break you
Comp Plan for variable is stupid

headline: AE
pros: Great culture. Very savvy and driven sales people.  Team environment.
cons: 100% work from the office.  High pressure to deliver on numbers.

headline: Hard work, but amazing!
pros:
The 1-1-1 Model here (google it) and a tangible benefit that results of it is 7 full days of VTO (volunteer time off) to be used responsibly at your discretion. Matching gifts to a non-profit of your choice. 

- Benefits here overall are incredible
- ESPP is attractive
- Time off is generous
- comp package works in your favor- i.e. hard work does in fact = revenue. 
- equipment is all up-to-date and excellent (iPhone as work phone, and MacBook as laptop)
- Training that consists of bootcamp in San Francisco, and further training at a local hub. Ongoing trailheads and updates also keep you on your toes. 
- Fast-paced environment 
- Great culture 
- Talented professionals 
- Collaborative environment across different segments 
- Brand recognition 
- Smooth employee processes in the background (payroll, time logged, benefit tracking, incentive tracking, employee profile, etc). 
- Continuous acquisitions of companies continues to strengthen our products and offerings. 
- Snacks, events, and happy hours
- Flexibility and autonomy given to consult with your clients 
- Networking opportunities here are endless
cons:
- You can feel "left-behind" here at times, so it's crucial to stay organized to keep up with the pace, especially early on. 
- Work-life balance (self-induced): it's easy to become attached to your work and your accounts, and it trickle over into your personal life after hours, or on weekends. 
- Difficult quota to hit, but that's for a reason. if this were easy I suppose they would let anyone in. 

Can't think of anything else. It's hard to find things wrong with Salesforce, in fact this section took me a lot longer to provide the bullet points above then the pros section.

headline: Dynamic Growth comes with pluses and minuses, but more pluses
pros:
Salesforce has a great culture and it's a company at which many employees feel proud to work . There's a real sense that we're making a difference both in our industry and through our philanthropy. The company is relentlessly focused on growth and anyone who has worked at place with 25% growth year after year after year, knows that there are growing pains.

Bulleted Pros:
Innovative company where ideas are given credence
1-1-1 model is real and matters to most people
Very smart, self-starting, motivated coworkers
cons:
Most of the cons can be summed up by growing pains. The rate of growth at times creates confusion and certainly poses organizational and system challenges. Salesforce is future focused and perhaps doesn't always take the time to look back to evaluate past performance, instead preferring to move on to the next big thing. The result is that sub-optimal processes don't always get corrected.

As the company has grown, a lack of focus on small details results in some areas of the business suffering until something serious occurs that draws attention to it. 

Salesforce is unabashedly a Customer Company. When given the choice to pivot to Customers, Shareholders, or Employees, the company will always choose Customers. This has resulted in the past with some haphazard and poorly though-through HR decisions. Lots of Employee-related initiatives seem to be thrown together at the last minute.

headline: High standards
pros: Talented people, high standards, relentless pursuit of goals, higher values, collaborative, agile, values-based, focused on doing well as a company and doing good for society, multistakeholder focused
cons: High performance, high intensity organization requires a full commitment of time and energy

headline: Technical Writer
pros: People are really enthusiastic and talented. The projects are typically well focused. A lot of opportunities to give back to the community.
cons: Work - life balance is not good. People are not willing (able?) to openly criticize management.

headline: Growing fast, continues to inspire, constant re-orgs
pros:
Witness one of the best in the world at selling and marketing enterprise software products
Great customer success stories
Visionary CEO
cons:
Title inflation
Unstructured career path
Sales-driven culture
Managers promoted for individual contribution, not leadership abilities

headline: Great ambitions and great team to reach them!
pros:
- high ambition of the team
- management very attentive to your expecations
- great team
- great life/work balance
- many social events to strengthen relationships with co-workers
cons:
- high expectations
- requires to be autonomous

headline: Customer Success Manager
pros:
- Excellent training
- Outstanding company culture that is focused on customer success and making the world a better place
- Colleagues are extremely helpful and collaborative
cons: A lot of learn and it is a very fast moving and changing company - not a con per se - but challenging to keep up.

headline: Diverse and friendly staff
pros: Diversity, challenges, impressive work-life balance.  Everyone so far wants to genuinely help progress the state of the art.
cons: Great deal of NIH, based on the requirements for data locality.  Best effort documentation sometimes is missing things.

headline: Great Company
pros: Unlimited career opportunities, good salary, constant innovation
cons: Getting a bit too much corporate

headline: Still very high potential
pros: Love my boss! He really seems to value my input and it's so good to be "heard." I don't think I would be here if it wasn't for him. Our philanthropic model is also such a great role model opportunity for me with my kids. I believe in the products we're delivering everyday. Our customers success is critical to the survival of Salesforce and that is evident in every interaction internally and externally.
cons: The company is fairly large now and it can be difficult to navigate who or where responsibilities lay. This isn't for the faint of heart or people who need a lot of directions. Independence, autonomy, and ambition must come with you or you will get lost in the shuffle.

headline: Great Company!
pros:
Was debating between this company and a few other large tech companies in the bay area. Was blown away by the culture and people here. It sounds cliche, but the people here are really what made me choose SalesforceIQ. Everyone is social, intelligent, and extremely helpful. Onboarding has been smooth and the development pace is much faster than what you'd find in a traditional tech company. 

You get the best of both worlds within SalesforceIQ - a startup environment that has the stability of a large company. Compensation is highly competitive with the bay area. SalesforceIQ was definitely one of the best choice I've made.
cons: None as of right now.

headline: Marketing Campaign Manager
pros: Challenging, fun and flexible work. Giving back to the communities. Great cultures.
cons: Some management team not good.

headline: Salesfore Contractor
pros: Good company to work for. Very smart people.
cons: Contract assignment wasn't extended due to budget. Don't really feel like a part of the team, because a contractor

headline: Good company
pros:
great culture
nice people
good work/life balance
lots of room for innovation in some teams.
cons:
some teams are very archaic and hard to innovate.
Soft and sometimes ineffective management

headline: Awesome company to work for! #dreamjob
pros:
- Visionary Leader 
- Product Growth
- Customer Growth and Success Stories
- Growing Developer Community
- Growing Customer Community
- Opportunities to grow internally
cons:
With growing pace, comes growing pains of hiring right talent and continue to be nimble and agile.
Growing competition from MSFT, Oracle, SNOW will make it harder to position unique values

headline: Great corp culture
pros:
- positive corp culture
- good product that works
- great benefits (including gym membership, wellness credits etc)
- fast paced, always changing, never a dull moment
cons:
- growing so fast that some of the new leaders are changing and influencing the corp culture for the worse
- sales teams are driven pretty hard, a lot of deals close at the last second of the last day in the quarter 'or else'

headline: Senior Supply Chain Analyst
pros: Good work life balance, great benefits,collaborative work environment,
cons: None, great place to work at.

headline: Great place to Work
pros:
Great Sales Training
Great Benefits (401K match, stocks plan and others)
cons: Very competitive environment, but it`s sales...

headline: I love this company
pros: Amazing culture, incredible product, they treat their people well, great benefits, great pay, innovative, fun....I will retire with this company!
cons: It moves fast and there's a lot to learn...but if you enjoy learning this isn't a con.

headline: I love this company
pros: Amazing culture, incredible product, they treat their people well, great benefits, great pay, innovative, fun....I will retire with this company!
cons: It moves fast and there's a lot to learn...but if you enjoy learning this isn't a con.

headline: Amazing experience
pros:
Teams were extremely helpful, drops everything to help you as an intern. 
Everyone was more concerned about your learning and experience than the work you end up making
cons: I can't really think of any

headline: Good Internship Program
pros:
Relaxed and great management for interns.
Recruiters put a lot of effort into internship program.
cons: Big company, sometimes too relaxed.

headline: great work life balance
pros: Employee friendly. great flexibility in terms of WFH and hours
cons: Can not think of any tons really. Based in San Francisco, so commute will be bad if you are traveling from s bay

headline: Hard Driving Sales Culture
pros: the pay, the pay, the pay.  Company has a great reputation, and I would review in working in other areas besides sales
cons: Track every single moment of your day.  Cold calling.  No flexibility within the sales teams

headline: Intern to Full Time
pros: I did 2 different stints of an internship at SalesforceIQ and what kept bringing me back was the team. Everyone I met there is fantastic, humble, and ready to dive into problems. The overall atmosphere was what brought be back into joining them full time. The internship experience really sets you up well to transferring to a full time position. Getting to work on actual problems showed me what it was like to work in the field and has set me up for success after transferring.
cons: Overall I think they've improved their internship over time, and they are always welcome to take feedback.

headline: A rollercoaster, pressure and pleasure all in one
pros: The company culture is positive, product is great, new opportunities are there all the time. Location is good and generally people are decent - no dopes are hired
cons: Shrinking patches make it harder to earn in some segments, its very much an american company with monthly targets , quarterly etc. Sometimes a bit over the top American vibe

headline: Customer Success Intern
pros: Amazing company and tons of training
cons: Tons of snacks but not varied from week to week

headline: Senior Manager Human Resources
pros: autonomy, salary, benefits, culture, ceo all pros
cons: poor mid level managers and management training

headline: Best place to work
pros: Equality, great product, great clients, zero clown environment, pay
cons: Long hours...that's really my only issue

headline: What a place to work!
pros:
- Constant communication so you are aware of all of the new and exciting things that are happening across the business
- Endless, amazing volunteering opportunities to give back to the community - 56 hours a year!
- Colleagues across the business listen and are interested in advising in terms of career development
- Lots of opportunity to learn and develop knowledge through seminars, round tables and lunch & learns
- Wellness is one of the key values at Salesforce and it definitely shows - our benefits are second to none!
cons:
- Some teams don't practice all of the values of Salesforce, they only focus in on a couple - transparency is one that I feel needs to be developed more
- London and Staines are very separate entities. By bringing more seminars and events to Staines, it will enrich the culture and lay some of the pressure off of the work space issue in London

headline: #1 Best Place to Work ad I agree!
pros: Excellent benefits, great culture, little or no 'hierarchy attitude', great management, inspiring leader, great education support, competitive salaries, benefits are great
cons: Location (not being city centre based) can be a hindrance at times unless you live out this direction but they really make the most of it and ample parking to accommodate! More of a personal con then a company con!

headline: Director
pros: Product is amazing and the focus on giving back is inspiring.
cons: Senior leadership and culture.  It is very political with an arrogant culture.  It also tends to be "helicopter" leadership out of the States, when senior US leaders get involved in areas they know nothing about.

headline: Culture keeps thrashing
pros: Great work life balance and focus on volunteering. Incredible company growth which creates opportunity within.
cons: The UX org has gone through 3 sets of leaders and management. The current leader makes you feel like a failure in every interaction which is very discouraging. We're dropping like flies and understaffed to begin with which is too bad because our CEO is amazing and the company is inspiring.

headline: Director
pros: Chatter drives culture at Salesforce
cons: Moving from a small to a very large organization, mind set of older employees

headline: Enterprise Focus with SME mentality
pros: Fast moving and very focus and capture everything in the system
cons: lost the human touch and focus more on system

headline: RVP
pros: Growth, product portfolio, startup environment
cons: Intensity, few processes, short experienced staff due to growth pace

headline: Great company
pros: Very competitive pay. Great workplace environment providing ergonomic assessments, stand up treadmill desks and healthy snack options.
cons: Salesforce is growing rapidly, and as a result is hiring a large volume of unqualified middle management. Additional processes slow down sales cycles.

headline: Incredibly Talented and Unique Company
pros:
Some of the most intelligent people I've ever worked with. The culture here is very unique, in that it feels like a family, and everyone is always genuine and friendly. 
The atmosphere here is great for learning, and you will always feel comfortable taking risks and doing something you ordinarily wouldn't feel comfortable doing. Working here will leverage your knowledge and skills, and test your creativity and intuition so that you will grow fast.
cons: I don't have any cons to list.

headline: Designer
pros: Good company culture that shares the right values to all employees and the society. Good salary and very considerate balancing work and life. Many talented co-workers, designers and engineers. Many people work from home and also keep efficiency.
cons: The company took many acquisitions, which leads to a geographically scattered team. Sometimes the remote collaboration is painful.

headline: Designer
pros: Good company culture that shares the right values to all employees and the society. Good salary and very considerate balancing work and life. Many talented co-workers, designers and engineers. Many people work from home and also keep efficiency.
cons: The company took many acquisitions, which leads to a geographically scattered team. Sometimes the remote collaboration is painful.

headline: my review
pros: cloud social mobile data science
cons: i can't think of one

headline: Sales Role
pros: Great Benefits!! Good Base Pay! Great Brand Recognition
cons: Very Tactical Sales Approach Month by month. Not strategic or consultative. Constantly managing by fear of PIPs.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Amazing place to work. Friendly atmosphere.
cons: Work load is more. Trying to balance the work and personal space is difficult.

headline: People operations
pros:
+ Super professional, thoughtful and swift interviewing process
+ Got to meet several folks on the team during my onsite so that I got a good feel for the range of personalities of my co-workers
+ The people all genuinely care about what they work on - and they uphold high standards
+ I enjoy working around and with my coworkers - be it over our catered meals or during our conference calls
cons: SalesforceIQ has startup roots, so the pace is fast and the performance expectations are high - it's important to call time out and make sure you take the time to leverage the resources. The team and leadership will help, but you need to take the initiative.

headline: Smart people, laid back culture
pros: People here are good at what they do and eager to help.
cons: Sometimes not as well-rounded - harder to introduce new ideas to people outside of their field(s) of expertise

headline: Account Executive
pros:
Very clear messaging.
Good sales product training.
Great product.
cons: Hired too many AE's.  Made territories smaller and, as a result, less than a third of the AE's make their numbers.

headline: Innovation, Results, Compassion
pros: Exec leadership is willing to take risk, reinvent itself.   They invest tremendous amounts in their employees.   Managers understand their success is predicated on the success and happiness of subordinates.  "Ohana (respect, family)" culture is incredible.
cons: Things change quickly.   If you are change-averse, then it might not be for you.

headline: Customer Intelligence trainee
pros: A great culture and good compensation
cons: The promotion path is already written and there are no exceptions for top performers.

headline: Great Place to be
pros: Innovative and Careful about our Society we are living in.
cons: Sales driven company requires to focus on Service as well

headline: Great Place to be
pros: Innovative and Careful about our Society we are living in.
cons: Sales driven company requires to focus on Service as well

headline: Feedback
pros:
Great company ethos
Great vision
Great people
Innovative products and marketing
cons: Have to leave at some point

headline: Technology
pros: Best in sales and marketing insights
cons: Minimum development program for wmpl

headline: Senior Marketing Manager
pros:
Everyone is very driven and ambitious 
Everyone is willing to help you navigate the business
Great growth opportunities
cons: There is no blueprint for on-boarding in various marketing roles - takes a lot of initiative to figure things out

headline: Salesforce Marketing Employee
pros: Excellent benefits - pension, health insurance, wellness grant and 7 days paid charity work.
cons: Work load and hours can be demanding.

headline: Great Growth Company
pros: Collaborative environment, feels like a startup.
cons: Transparency from the top is a bit lacking.

headline: Best company to work for
pros: Startup work environment with a laid back team culture
cons: Not much of a con, but be prepared to work long hours.

headline: Quality Enginner
pros: Relaxed culture, really nice manager, go back home early, volunteering tradition
cons: The code base is complex and burdensome

headline: Senior Solutions Architect
pros: People, the company culture and attitude towards customers and the community. Everyone helps you and to find information is made very easy. This company feels like a family and there is all the time things happening with new stuff coming up.
cons: You need to keep the focus on balance between personal and work life. It is easy to get crazy when you start as a new employee because there is so much information and it is so easy to get it.

headline: Great company, strong leadership
pros: Benefits, Company Culture, Company Values and Innovation
cons:
-Rapidly expanding product line
-High turnover

headline: Unique Culture
pros: Great place to grow and learn under the security of a large corporation, but the uniqueness of a start up.
cons: Demanding hours and fast-paced culture. Hard to keep up with all the "new" things.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great people, friendly and welcoming culture
cons: Growing quickly causes some pain

headline: Greatest place I've ever worked.
pros:
This place attracts the best of the best and quickly weeds out those who don't want to be here which makes for a great work environment. That toxic co-worker who complains regularly about your manager, or company, they don't last long here.

You will know quickly whether you belong in sales because this place is intense. If you can make it then you will earn a life changing amount of money, given opportunities for professional development, and your career will open up vastly.

Everything in the media about our culture, innovation, etc, it's all true. And it makes this a truly incredible place to work.

I'm very proud of working at Salesforce because it's a company that stands behind it's values every step of the way.
cons: There are a LOT of products to understand. The days of it being a simple CRM are far behind it and while you don't have to be an expert in every area, there are experts available most of the time, you do need to know enough to be dangerous. And that takes time. While you're learning the products the ramp is closing so if you have accounts that need TLC you can get in the weeds quickly.

headline: Great Internship Enviroment
pros: I had the flexibility from my managers to grow my own project, as well as the opportunity to interact with multiple teams in the company
cons: None that I can think of. Honest!

headline: Heaven or Hell???
pros:
Salesforce tries really hard to maintain the culture of startup while growing and expanding its business to meet market demand.

Lots of perks, especially in US and for office based employees.

If you can find the time, the VTO model can be rewarding for all concerned. 

Broad customer appeal, ongoing innovation.

Some employees absolutely love the place and the culture - almost cult like belief which can be both a wonderful place of happiness and also slightly concerning!
cons:
Too many processes, not communicated consistently across the business - result most people are very busy - but not very productive!  

Looking to shoe horn acquired businesses into what are already broken core processes - consequence of which is frustration all round.  

Too much focus on trailhead and mandatory virtual learning, information overload and simply not enough hours in the day to get the job done.   Compared to other enterprise software companies fewer class room based opportunities for learning.

Painful on-boarding process, sink or swim.

Surprising lack of resources.  For many not a sustainable place to work.

headline: fun experience
pros: Recruiters put a lot of effort into creating good events for interns, great culture
cons: Not all interns had projects that were meaningful and worked out well

headline: success manager
pros: good company so far. hard to say
cons: forces benefit rules that don't always make sense.

headline: Principal Success Manager
pros: Perks! Flexibility benefits; ohana; nice people
cons: disorganized; changing priorities; ad hoc

headline: Great company but becoming more like other big corporations.
pros: Culture is great; Great people; Company strategy and direction are awesome; If you love giving back through service you'll love the philanthropic culture!  The CEO is motivating, engaged, does the right things and has a big heart.
cons: The company moves fast and it re-orgs all the time.   If you don't like constant manager and job changes, Salesforce isn't a good fit.  Even with all the great things about Salesforce, it's behaving more like the other big companies.  For example, after re-orgs the "HR" team will do job audits to "align" individual's job codes to fit the new org. regardless of it having a devastating impact to an individual's comp. (20-25% or more cut) and even if the job responsibilities are exactly the same.  This kind of rigid conformity by front line HR workers is demotivating in a fast changing environment.

headline: Business Development Representative
pros: In Indy, the people, environment, and culture are what really sets Salesforce Marketing Cloud apart from other places I have worked. The people that are hired in Indianapolis, are a different breed than most-in a good way. I am in sales, and we are a sales family, rather than everyone being selfish and only out for themselves.
cons: Other Salesforce hubs don't seem to be cut from the same cloth when it comes to the different parts of sales. Indy is also the main Marketing Cloud hub so we have to work with the other sales teams within Salesforce who sell the other products that we offer. Some would rather get their money than do what is best for the customer. It's difficult to work across the different hubs sometimes because of this.

headline: Good, well-meaning folks who could do better
pros:
-People (usually) listen well
-Company invests in training its people
-Great benefits and pay
cons:
-It's a lumbering corporate behemoth; hard to change things
-Concierge and Chatter are soul killing; it doesn't feel very much like "ohana" when you don't have a person you can talk to about benefits/HR things easily in person`
-More concerned about hurting white guys' feelings than actually making changes to become more inclusive

headline: Senior Member of Technical Staff
pros:
- Great place to work in general
- V2MOM is an excellent way to align the company's goals
- great benefits including paid time off to volunteer, RRSP matching, generous paid time off, etc
- depending on what project you're on, you get to work with modern technologies
- excellent technical team
cons:
- In some cases management has little interest in the careers of those below them
- There doesn't seem to be much interest in hiring less experienced people (including co-ops)
- Acquisitions need to be integrated in a faster manner, and don't let them think they will keep their own branding and processes for long
- Because the company is so huge, you tend not to know what is going on in the rest of the organization

headline: Nice Place
pros: Good Perks, Employees all driven
cons: Bloated Management, Hard to get ahead

headline: Lots to love. Of course, no workplace is perfect.
pros: The benefits -- 401k and donation match, ESPP, maternity, many expenses covered -- are great. I got lucky and have an awesome manager. I also enjoy working remotely. Being able to contribute to Dreamforce is a plus. They definitely make an effort to be transparent and communicative here. If you have a cool idea, Salesforce is a place where you can often make it a reality.
cons: Why is drinking such a big part of the company culture? It saddens me that even a below-21 intern feels he/she can't participate fully in the "culture" because drinking is such a "big part" of it, as seen in a recent Glassdoor review. I don't drink for health reasons, and I often feel like work events (holiday parties, team celebrations, Dreamforce) are less rewarding for me because the non-alcoholic choices are an afterthought. Can I have a $20 gift card instead?! I've seen a lot of employees misbehaving and embarrass themselves through alcohol. Time to cut back. Alcohol is not the same thing as a company culture. Second, I have no illusions that working remotely is a perfect situation. I know I miss out on a lot in the office and I am ok with it. That said, I think the company could do more to make Salesforce better for non-SF members of the Ohana. I also think there should be better career paths for those who are not managers. Because I'm remote, I have been told I don't have much room to move up since I can't manage remotely (even though my manager manages me remotely... and that seems to work fine). The company expects so much of us during Dreamforce (12+ hour days for a week), but we never see any time off as a result of that.

headline: Lack of International business focus
pros: Great company, great brand, great culture, great products, excellent 1:1:1 policy.
cons: Lack of international market focus, Exec visits, investment,  low standard marketing leadership roles that deal with politics more than actual work and delivery of progress. No action from top management.

headline: Vice President
pros: Salesforce is hands down the best place I have ever worked, great people, great technology and the best culture in the world.
cons: Salesforce has grown dramatically over the last 4 years, from 8k employees to 21k.  With this growth comes opportunity and challenges.  We must continue to keep our eye on the culture to insure that new members of the Ohana are brought in with the same care as prior employees.

headline: AE review
pros: Product is great with very strong mobile offering. Strong business focused sales process.  Create and demonstrate a vision for transformation. Develop roadmap and ROI. Lots of resources to assist.
cons: Growth is sustained by carving territories for new reps. Frustrating to lose accounts you invest in, and need to drive bigger deals in reduced territory.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Salesforce provides a ton of sales enablement material to learn all about digital marketing technology and you work with smart companies.
cons: It's gotten way too big and Salesforce puffs out it's big chest and considers it a privilege if companies become clients.  Way too much boasting  You're a cog in a wheel and will report to several different people there.  New territories are given out without any input from AEs.  You're successful if you have a good territory and it depends if Salesforce has pissed off that company in the past.  If so - good luck!

headline: Brilliant but some growing pains
pros: All the other pro reviews are spot on, innovative, fast paced and hungry to do more and grow. Recently started to also ensure internal promotion was increased.
cons: Becoming more corporate as the larger consultancies and service providers hemorrhage staff to Salesforce. But on the whole they tend to adopt the new culture.

headline: Excellent, if a little disorganized internship experience
pros: They give awesome perks, fun events, and my assigned team was filled with really great people. The interview was pretty easy too. Casual every day.
cons: There's no food, if that's a deal breaker, but you're in the middle of the Financial District of SF, so...not really a problem. FutureForce is a very young program, so the recruiting staff is really disorganized, but I think it'll get better in future years.

headline: Awesome Intern Experienc
pros: Great pay, great culture, everybody is willing to answer questions and teach you about your specific job as well jobs of other people in the department, and great intern specific events.
cons: The only con is that if you are under 21 you cant drink, and drinking is a big part of their company culture.

headline: Great benefits, but lots of room for improvement
pros:
+ Many smart, nice people
+ Company values are easy to get behind and alignment is really good
+ Outstanding benefits, pay, VTO
+ Tons of training available, room for movement within the company
+ Lots of hard problems to solve
cons:
- Everything is centered around keeping Individual Contributors happy, but Managers & above do not get the same treatment 
- Politics are awful among those wrangling for influence & looking to climb
- Top-down decisions are pushed onto managers and teams
- Too many meetings
- Unproductive build environment for thousands of engineers, and forced use of homegrown tools & technologies that are inferior to commercial & open source ones 

It's a HUGE company with different subcultures in different divisions, this just describes one.

headline: Senior account executive
pros: Innovation, speed, excellence, customer success, leader, trust, unified platform, digital transformation, nice offices, american company, new product, marketing, client office, platform, digital transformation, nice offices, american company, new product,
cons: Salesforce put a lot of Pressure on the account executives, territories are schrinking dramaticaly, not many AE achieve their quotas.

headline: Great Company, Long Hours
pros: Progressive, inclusive company with vision
cons: Employees overworked, bad departmental management

headline: Summer Intern
pros: Great culture and incredibly smart people!
cons: The company has some catching up to do because of the rapid growth.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros:
The company culture is fantastic. The value that we all share is "Ohana" -- family. The work environment is friendly,  supportive, inclusive. At my new employee orientation an SVP told us that the top three values are: honesty, kindness, meeting commitments. Kindness?? I couldn't believe it, but it turns out to be true

The work is very challenging but fun. My coworkers are smart, motivated, talented. We have fun!  And, the culture is not one of 60-90 hr workweeks. People here are more mature.
cons: I can't think of any

headline: Senior Director
pros: Still a leader in the industry so long as customers see value
cons: Lack of investment in current employees. Random career policies.

headline: Great company
pros: Really try to sell you on how great the company culture and benefits are, which there definitely are a lot of.
cons: No real cons to share, only thing I would say is that it is a very typical industry job (a "boring" 9-5).

headline: Great Company as long as you are in the right Org.
pros: Great perks, well-respected, great pay.
cons: If you fit in the culture, than all is good. If not, might not be the place for you.

headline: So much to like but internal politics are frustrating
pros:
There are many, many reasons why salesforce is a great company and awesome place to work. Top for me:
1. True focus on customer success and giving back through volunteering
2. Co-workers are smart, driven, and work hard
3. Overall great benefits
cons: After 5+ years at the company, I notice that internal politics seem to be getting worse. Lots of blame and finger-pointing with less collaboration than I'd like at very top levels of management; really disappointing to see first-hand how some very senior members of the Sales org are difficult to work with and (at times) outright unprofessional.

headline: Technical Recruiter
pros:
Smart leadership 
Aggressive growth goals that push the team to be strong performers 
Work/life balance
cons:
Political environment 
Lots of middle management 
Big enough company for weak performers to find a place to hide, undetected 
Hiring freezes
Over titled and over leveled culture (perhaps for retention)

headline: Good work/life balance
pros: They don't drive you as hard as other companies. Culture, compensation and benefits are good,
cons: It's a big company, you don't have a get a huge amount of variety.

headline: I love Salesforce!!
pros: Pros include Marc Benioff! SFDC culture, trust, transparency, set up in an environment for success, growth opportunities, innovation, giving back, equality! and Ohana
cons: No cons from my perspective. I am an outside sales professional with ten plus years experience and I recently joined SFDC. This is my dream job come true.

headline: Good job to get feet wet.
pros: Company size, promotion opportunity, large market, good social/work life
cons: Poor middle management in some locations

headline: RVP
pros: Company continues to innovate and put clients 1st
cons: Internal tensions between various sales team. Little collaborate and too much fingerpointing

headline: Salesforce interview
pros:
Culture, mindset, growth experiences, customer feedback. Best place I have worked at, quality of colleagues is absolutely top quartile. Pay and benefits top drawer, but mostly it's the companies zealous focus on customer value that makes the job feel a lot more authentic.

There is a real start up mentality here which means that growth opportunities are plenty. 

Onboarding is great, best I have had.
cons: Volume of work, location - everything takes place within the tower, difficult to break out although I do work from home or Staines 2 days a week.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Sales Machine
Great Support and Sales Enablement
Competitive Environment
60 hours paid VTO
Amazing Product
cons:
Work Life Balance
Lots of Prospecting

headline: SMB Account Executive
pros: Great sales training and career opportunities. SFDC and Force.com are market leading products but a lot of the acquisition products are sub standard and haven't been improved since been acquired,
cons: Management politics significantly impact on the effectiveness of the organisation. Promotions and territory allocations are based on relationship instead of rep performance.

headline: One of the best company to work for
pros:
Good Compensation
Challenging work but very less burden
Very Good Perks
Employee Caring
cons:
Compensation could be better
Career Opportunities are vague

headline: Account executive
pros: Great place to work! very collaborative and empowering people.
cons: Mexico's office is growing very fast, we need  more hands.

headline: Truly is a great place to work.
pros: Literally everything you're looking for, is here at Salesforce. They offer great compensation & benefits, tons of flexibility, the best work/life balance, lots of opportunity for growth, and at the end of the day - the people here are genuinely nice! People are willing to help if ever you need it, and everyone is respectful of each other. Without a doubt, the best place I've ever worked.
cons: Being apart of such a big company, it is sometimes hard to see or feel the impact you make. I'll always feel like a small fish in a very, very big pond.

headline: Great place to work if you put in the effort
pros:
- Smart and driven colleagues
- Challenging work
- Intelligent and impressive executives
- Flexible hours
- Paid volunteer time off
- Great health, family and vacation benefits
cons: Salesforce is a big company so it is easy to get swept away if you are not taking control of your career. I wouldn't call this a con necessarily because I think it is any individuals job to make the most of his/her career. If things aren't working the way you want them to, then do something about it. Complaining doesn't fix problems.

headline: Culture has changed
pros: Overall, I feel like the right messages are being sent from the very top. Take care of yourself, be kind and consider the people you work with family. For a large company, things move reasonably quickly. In the SF office, the have a great company café, wellness centers and even places to drop your dog off while you work. Comp, perks and benefits are pretty solid and almost up there with the likes of Google or Facebook.
cons: The culture has significantly changed. A year ago I was proud and excited to be a part of the company. The Lightning release was a shining moment for how the company's culture can facilitate great things. However, there have been a number of changes over the last year that have slowly eroded the magic - starting with some of the new leadership. Our group has become more fragmented and less collaborative. There's more fear of making mistakes and the general sense of trust and support for our work from our leadership has gone way down. The transparency and access we had upwards is becoming more hazy largely because of layers being added. My autonomy and empowerment to make decisions is slipping away. Politics were always there, but now they're something you have to consider daily. You used to be judged based on the work you created and what you shipped, it doesn't feel that way anymore. Some of my favorite people have already moved on. Perhaps it's just the nature of a company growing this fast. There's not a clear avenue for safely giving upwards feedback for our group. My hope is that someone up top takes notice and makes corrections.

headline: Account Executive - Emerging Small Businesses
pros: Great culture! Fast paced with tons of room for growth and advancement in your career.
cons: Salary is not as competitive as what other companies in this industry offer

headline: Regional Vice President
pros: Fast paced, great people, solutions are mature and customers very happy with them, leadership is remarkable, the company growing like crazy.  You can make really, really great money.  Recruiters will go after you hard once you've been here a year so great career move.
cons: If you don't want to work your butt off this isn't the right place.  However, if you like a fast pace you can do really well here (everybody says they are fast paced but not like this...).   If you like to chill choose another company

headline: Sales
pros: Great company with strong vision and leadership.  Good benefits with volunteer opportunities to give back to local community.
cons: Growing pains with a fast paced environment.  Leadership is working to provide better work life balance however no near term end in sight.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Love the management transparency and support you receive. Very collaborative and progressive. Love being on the cutting edge. Senior Management meeting are broadcast live to all employees.
cons: Very fast paced - you'll be running from day 1. Changes in management and personnel not well communicated.

headline: Excellent people and culture allows you to do your best for your customers
pros:
Real Drive and Passion Customers and People
Focus on community on Social issues is real rather than lip service
Agility to get things done quickly
Accelerated Growth
Excellent offices
Fast paced
cons: Fast Paced - if you are not used to a fast growing company this could be a challenge. Personally it has helped me thrive in the first 6 months and it motivates me to see the pace of growth and change

headline: One of the most dynamic, innovative and fast growing company on the market!
pros: Young, dynamic, competitive, fast growing. Salaries above the average of the market. Due to the fact that is growing so fast, every day there are new opportunities, both for internal and external candidates
cons: At the moment i don't see particular cons except for the location, Dublin. If you like sales and you are competitive, this is the place for you

headline: Amazing Company
pros: Amazing benefits, stock options, 35 days of vacation, wellness reimbursement, education reimbursement. The company really cares about their employees.
cons: Main headquarters are in San Francisco, so if you want to be near all the activity you have to live there. Cost of living is ridiculous.

headline: Amazing Company
pros: Amazing benefits, stock options, 35 days of vacation, wellness reimbursement, education reimbursement. The company really cares about their employees.
cons: Main headquarters are in San Francisco, so if you want to be near all the activity you have to live there. Cost of living is ridiculous.

headline: Atlanta's best place to work!
pros: Great company and benefits with a culture of a start-up.
cons: I have yet to find any cons working here.

headline: Marketing - great team but suffers from wider organisation
pros:
Great culture and team spirit
Philanthropy 
Fun
Office location
First and second line managers
cons:
Politics, politics, politics.

Pay increases ok but only if you started on the right amount. Tend to hire young, on a low salary and pretty soon falls way behind market value.

Career paths for marketing non existent. Limited progression options.

Top down approach. Hard to make a real impact from the bottom up. Need to wait for somebody senior to have the same idea or claim yours as their own.

Hq driven. EMEA afterthought at best.

headline: Strategic Events
pros: Fun and exciting environment for the employees.
cons: Hard to get noticed for your work

headline: Great place to be
pros: Superb culture, great work environment, leading edge products and services, innovates at pace, growing fast
cons: Its getting more complex, the change cycle is continuous, expecting to be selling something regardless of your role

headline: Data Center Engineer
pros: There's always work to do.
cons: Overworked, underappreciated, bad management, disorganized, and expected to work weekends ...do not expect to work only 40 hours a week.

headline: Great opportunities
pros: Hyper growth, great products to market, fantastic customers and a company with a soul and values that make coming to work every day fun.
cons: Work can be extremely busy at times when preparing for the main events of the year: Salesforce World Tour Paris or Dreamforce.

headline: Pleasantly Surprised New-Grad
pros: Salesforce is the first company I have worked for full-time, so I can't compare it to any other company, but I have quickly developed a deep admiration, appreciation, and sense of pride for my company. I was pleasantly surprised that my first job out of college (at Salesforce) gave me the liberty to explore projects, innovate and build out my own ideas, and meet frequently with executives and leaders throughout the 20k+ employee company. My work feels important and my interactions with Salesforce customers and employees are unmistakably friendly and unmistakably Salesforce.
cons: Like at any enterprise tech company, the work is big and complex. With responsibility over projects that affect hundreds to thousands of people, balancing work priorities and personal life can feel a bit rocky at times. Fortunately, there is always a bright mind to turn to for help and no shortage of motivated, hard-working people around you to get the job done and have a little fun while doing it.

headline: A good place to work if you can deal with the politics and power games
pros: Competitive environment, very focused on growth, very strong goal setting. Great perks (benefits, remote work support), fair but not amazing salary.
cons: Very strong politics and somewhat negative orientation in the market for their customers. Rely on big services and other upsells. Widely varying levels of success depending on the integration partner. NOT focused on new features and innovation, but milking the existing stack for maximum revenue.

headline: Awesome company - Awesome benefits
pros: So much benefits - so much interesting work - face-paced company that will make you want to stay here forever.
cons: Bureaucracy - Internal framework sucks - top down approach in engineering -

headline: Recruiter
pros: -Great People, autonomy to control your career, pay meets industry standards
cons: -Can be a struggle depending on the group you support, you are either really busy or its super slow.

headline: Manager
pros: Free snacks and Free cofee
cons:
The worst work life balance than any company I have worked for. They only care about growing revenue at any cost and the most short term focussed company. Employees have to turn around everything within 24 hours irrespective of personal priorities. Expected to work weekends with no compensation for long hours out in
The Sales culture is a mess with large attrition as nobody wants to stay longer with such short term focus

headline: Great growing company
pros:
Great company culture
Great CEO
People are respected
Company has a good priority in security
Politics is not bad compared to other companies
Company loves San Francisco
cons:
Company is growing so there are some growing pains
Has 401k, but no retirement plan, which is normal for these days
No free lunch, can't think of another Cons

headline: Okay place
pros: Great people. Good training. Can make good money.
cons: Not the best leadership - extremely micromanaging and transactional.

headline: Business Development Representative
pros:
Competitive Compensation
Free onsite snacks and drinks
Salesforce really offers the ability of someone to start from the bottom and work their way up to the top. It is a great place to start a career in IT and are the market leaders in their field of business.
cons:
Constant changes to focus and mission.
Unclear direction on the "right way" to do things
Alignment is difficult for this role as you have managers and AE's that you have to stay in lock step with.
Loosing focus on culture and more concern for driving numbers and revenue than anything else.

headline: Vice President of Sales, AMER
pros: Great products and people (for the most part).  Benefits and office environment is great.  Accountability and ownership are big value drivers for those who seek independence.
cons: Monthly cadence for sales organization is difficult.  The pressure to perform monthly sometimes works at cross purposes of developing a trusted advisor/relationship status with your clients.

headline: Marketing Manager
pros: Invested career development, creativity, ability to move around
cons: Can be disorganised at times

headline: Dreamjob
pros: The culture and constant search for improvement and making things better
cons: Red tape in some processes

headline: Good for your resume!
pros:
rah rah culture is infectious
well respected company
excellent tools and technology company wide
cons:
diversity? what diversity? White men and white people everywhere
once the rose colored glasses come off, one has to decide whether I'll stay or I'll go

headline: A good place to be
pros: Good perks, pay, and work life balance
cons: This is a sales company, not a tech company. No one is working on cutting edge research or sinking resources into developing novel systems. You are building CRM software.

headline: It comes from the top
pros:
SMB team has a real entrepreneurial spirit
People care about each other
Constantly developing and challenging environment
CEO sets the tone through passion and vision and is a genuinely good person
CSR is core to everything we do
Promotion opportunities are everywhere in Dublin
cons:
Not for the faint-hearted
The sense of mission and associated demands will not be for everyone - be prepared to work hard.
As the company gets larger and the product set gets wider, the resilience factor is increased. New employees need to be prepared to wait 9-12 months before things "click".

headline: Account executive
pros: Great product, team and people. Training is top notch. Benefits and perks are great, as you'd expect, and obviously you have the brand recognition to get your foot in the door.
cons:
Unrealistic quota goals. Every single month feels like it's end of quarter, and end of quarters feel like end of year. End of year is just insane. The pressure every single month is tough to deal with and especially in ESMB, quotas are just not realistic. Big deals tough to come by.

You'd expect a sales role at Salesforce to have plenty of inbound leads or plenty of add on business for existing customers - really not the case. Ton of outbound, cold calling, hunting role (but in your limited account base of course). 

Be ready to have literally everything questioned and expected to tell your manager absolutely everything going on in any deal at all times. You'll be questioned on everything you do. 

The culture in the NYC office is nothing like the other offices. When there are events or happy hours, everyone is too busy or exhausted to even go. Very much a heads down and focus kind of atmosphere.

Path to promotion is VERY political. Be prepared to play the game to move up.

headline: Incompentant managers and Non Competitve Wave Analytics product
pros: Decent compensation and wide selection of affordable benefits
cons: Management glaringly incomplete / arrogant! the wave analytics product should of never been released...at least another 18 months of basic development needed... Couldn't do basic analytics functions, nowhere on the Gartner Magic quadrant, and dropped price so much that reps can't make any money unless it's an added line item on a large non Wave deal

headline: Not disclosed
pros:
Ohara culture! (Check YouTube)
Great Core Values
No hierarchies (all ideas welcomed)
4th Enterprise Software Company in the world
Most Innovative company in the world according to Forbes for 6 years in a row
Giving back to Society scheme is unique and rewarding
Amsterdam office is sitting on the greenest building in the world
cons:
Fast Growth can be harder to manage
Limited parking places in the amsterdam office
Have not Found too many disadvantages yet

headline: Nothin' but Net
pros:
Salesforce is amazing. I truly think the company is a game changer, not only for the cloud computing and tech industry, but for corporations worldwide. The company's focus on philanthropy and making the world a better place are second to none. 

The pay is decent. I've heard that companies like Amazon pay more but  don't offer the same perks and nowhere near the same work-life balance.

The perks are great - onsite snacks, adjustable stand-up/sit-down desks, ping pong tables, "hang out" areas, commuter benefits and a wellness plan: $100 per month for activities including fitness facility fees, massages, etc.
cons: None! Nada! Nil! Zero! Zilch!

headline: Highly recommend
pros: Very supportive team culture.  Comparable salary and benefits. Sr execs keep team informed.  Very open and supportive leadership.  Plenty of training and certification opportunities.
cons: Growing pains from size on internal processes.  Hard to say a con as the team is highly active in streamlining.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Relaxed atmosphere filled with people who show no regard for the typical corporate hierarchy and are aways willing to help out the little guy.
cons: Apart from the fact that the Dublin office isn't in a very central location, there is not a whole lot of negatives about the company.

headline: Senior Director
pros: Great company to work for.
cons: roles are sliced too thin. business still tilted towards the core sfa and service cloud business.

headline: 12 Months In...Salesforce London
pros:
A highly invigorating, creative and energised place to work.  My experience of Salesforce is that of being at a true epi-centre, driving change, creating success and working with customers to shape the digital future.
The ohana family culture is represented throughout the organisation, with a strong employee benefits, great facilities and the most proactive and visible ways to give back and engage within communities.
cons: With so many resources to access and great tools, Salesforce is highly process driven.  The slight downside is that there is a need to maintain the personalised aspects of people management.

headline: Great Place to Work!
pros: Culture is incredible, very dynamic, many opportunities to shine!
cons: Very intense, priorities often change too quickly.

headline: Salesforce review
pros: Working for salesforce makes one feel like being part of something bigger than oneself. Management is fair and very transparent with decisions. Lots of fun activities.
cons: sometimes having to work long hours. This is not mandatory.

headline: Marketing Intern
pros: Probably the best internship I've ever had. The intern events are all very organized and super fun, the company is so welcoming, my team is amazing, I'm doing REAL projects (not just intern projects). Overall a great experience
cons: Really can't think of any cons.

headline: Cool work life balance, No free lunch or dinner
pros: Work is good, people are friendly
cons: You don't get free lunch or dinner, unlike many other companies in proximity. Google, Facebook, Twitter, Uber are just a few to name.

headline: order taker
pros:
great training
if you get a good territory you're set
cons: sales territories are getting small

headline: What more could you want!
pros: Great team environment. Fabulous company with great benefits. Salesforce is constantly innovating and growing, but they care tremendously about keeping the Ohana (family) culture. It's not just lip service...it's a true measurable, prioritized value.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Great Culture, Company and Products
pros: Awesome culture, products that are winning in the market and helping customers, great compensation and benefits.
cons: Still working to understand the career opportunities for remote employees.

headline: Suffering growing pains, but its heart is very much in the right place
pros: Without doubt the majority of the employees at Salesforce are wonderful, combining intellectual rigour with a fierce determination to do the right thing for our customers. The Ohana (broadly interpreted as family) culture is a real living culture, that imbues most people's behaviours.  People help each other, and are not focused on trying to get one over on each other.  The company is very much in growth mode, which makes for optimism and a sense of purpose.
cons: The company is at something of a crossroads, wedded to some of the disadvantages of its start-up mentality: thinking can be short-term, with decisions accordingly myopic, and there is too great a value placed on the diving-catch.  Too many fire-drills and a small number of capricious senior leaders who have been around for 10 - 15 years behaving in the same way.  It is tiresome, disruptive and frankly counter-cultural but their tenure appears to make them untouchable.

headline: First Year at Salesforce
pros: Innovative, Fun, Happy, Collaborative teams, exciting products and services
cons: not enough time in the day to take it all in!!

headline: Customer Reference Program, Marketing Trainee
pros:
If you enjoy working in a fast pace, innovative, collaborative environment then Salesforce is the company for you!
As market leaders, Salesforce was named as one of Fortunes top ten best places to work which I whole heartedly agree with. Salesforce is only 17 years old and taking the industry by storm. It is an amazing place to work, especially as the company changes & grows at such a fast pace.
cons: As the company is quite young, there are not necessarily processes in place which can sometimes make things challenging, especially when it come to career development however, the lack of process gives employees the opportunity to build their own processes and own their own career.

headline: Business Development Rep. in Dublin
pros:
-Startup attitude in a Fortune 500 company
-Company really growing with a product you can believe in and feel confident about when you speak to customers
-Very good atmosphere in the office, full of young, multicultural people.
-Fun culture spread around the company
-Some perks, like free drinks and snacks, fitness reimbursement and salaries above the average in the sector 
-Clear and recognisable career path
cons:
-Even though there's a general relaxed attitude, you can feel pressure coming from multiple and different fronts demanding results
-There's a general trend in the whole company to not respect working hours or when someone is on holidays, and to demand replies to emails and actions even though people are not working
-One of the two offices in Dublin, Central Park, could be severely improved: having a proper canteen with lunch and breakfast menus, more parking spaces, more desks (there are 120 desks for over 300 account executives), more meeting rooms...
-Some decisions coming from the top management lately have been done, in my impression, with the sense of being improvised and without the sufficient transparency towards the rest of the organisation.

headline: Business Development Rep. in Dublin
pros:
-Startup attitude in a Fortune 500 company
-Company really growing with a product you can believe in and feel confident about when you speak to customers
-Very good atmosphere in the office, full of young, multicultural people.
-Fun culture spread around the company
-Some perks, like free drinks and snacks, fitness reimbursement and salaries above the average in the sector 
-Clear and recognisable career path
cons:
-Even though there's a general relaxed attitude, you can feel pressure coming from multiple and different fronts demanding results
-There's a general trend in the whole company to not respect working hours or when someone is on holidays, and to demand replies to emails and actions even though people are not working
-One of the two offices in Dublin, Central Park, could be severely improved: having a proper canteen with lunch and breakfast menus, more parking spaces, more desks (there are 120 desks for over 300 account executives), more meeting rooms...
-Some decisions coming from the top management lately have been done, in my impression, with the sense of being improvised and without the sufficient transparency towards the rest of the organisation.

headline: Awesome Culture!
pros: The people are the smartest breed. The sales team is creative and passionate. Overall you'll learn a lot just by spending 2 years here. I spent 6 and it was the best 6 years of my career!
cons: They will make you work for the promotions. Example: you do 200% of your sales target and you're next in line for a promotion. Management will tap 3 people. You have now earned the right to interview for a promotion. You will be given a case study to present to senior directors. You will get beaten up in this meeting far beyond what any customer would put you through. At the end 1 of the 3 people will be selected to move up. The other 2 go back and wait until they are tapped again for a promotion. I watched a few friends depart due to not getting their promotion.

headline: Acquisition has been rough on veteran SteelBrickers
pros:
The foundation of why SteelBrick was a great place to work still exists in small amounts; great employees, caring and friendly environment, opportunities to move your career forward, etc.
 
- Salesforce has brought on some nice benefits like Volunteer Time Off (VTO), and access to more resources about the SFDC ecosystem that we already lived in as a separate company. So it's been great for employees who were already passionate about this space. 

-Working at Salesforce now has opened doors to try out new roles in other teams and transfer internally.

-Non-sales SteelBrick employees work out of a nice building in SF with great perks; free catered lunches, on-site gym, yoga classes, meditation, etc. Sales team works out of HQ SF office and enjoys being closer to core AE's.
cons:
- The Salesforce acquisition changed a lot of things about the culture, positions, teams, and leadership of SteelBrick for the worse (as expected with any acquisition, but still tough to manage). 

- The acquisition happened so fast (announcement to close ~1 month), that it barely gave employees time to process. The business had to be wrapped up and packaged for SFDC so quickly that employees were basically handed their offer letters and told 'sign now and we'll figure out logistics about how your position will change later'.

-The lack of communication during the acquisition, on boarding, and transition process created a divide between leadership and employees, causing distrust in leadership. Employees were commonly given answers about the future of their positions with 'we're not sure yet, we're working on it, and we'll let you know when we figure things out'.

- SteelBrick leadership focused primarily on their money-making teams (sales and dev) as their priority to ensure a smooth transition. The other teams we're offered positions with Salesforce, but haven't been given the opportunity to get the same improvements. The leadership team is only willing to fight for the teams that make more money for them.

- The further we get into Salesforce, the more we've lost our personal identity and culture. There's not as many fun events or opportunities for employees to come together and enjoy some time off. Everyone's too overworked and underpaid to want to stay around the office longer then they have to.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Good work life balance, perks
cons: None that exist so far

headline: Progression for women doesn't exist
pros: Great products, some fantastic open leaders. Great team spirit and you are given the tools to get your job  done. If only I was born a male I could probably have stayed!
cons: If you are a woman you will spend years trying to break through the extremely tight knit boys club. What makes it even harder is the PR about women completely contradicts the experience of many women who work here. The boys network will actively exclude women and block them as they fear they will do a better job. Mostly male leadership teams and now great women are leaving and being replaced by men.

headline: Recruiter
pros: Lots of jobs to fill
cons: Poor planning and support.

headline: Great, but growing
pros: Growing, with lots of opportunity.
cons: Growth causes a lot of change.  Territories move a lot.

headline: Fast paced
pros:
Endless learning opportunities
True Ohana culture/Collaborative
Awesome smart people to work with
Great benefits
cons:
Too fast paced
work life balance can be tricky
High pressure constantly changing environment

headline: Engineer
pros: Loved working here. Good perks.
cons: Management is wishy washy & indecisive.

headline: 12 month review
pros:
Company spirit
People are generally nice to work with, talented and considerate
Quality of the office and facilities
Benefits package
cons:
Product issues
Pre-sales process (overpromising clients)
M.Cloud feels like a collection of companies rather than 1 org
No classroom training

headline: AE
pros: Decent amount of marketing and specialist resources to help in technology positioning.
cons: Revolving door of reps.  Account list is sparse.  Pressure for revenue is monthly and not quarterly.  average AE lifespan is 12mos or less.  Management pressures internal recruiting to hire as they will never be at capacity in reps due to the constant turnover.

headline: Looking for an internship you will never forget?
pros: Coming into the summer with a couple different work experiences, SalesforceIQ provided one of the best internship experiences anyone could ask for. Emphasizing their values, it was evident that they placed a high importance on their people. The people at SalesforceIQ are some of the brightest, hard working and friendliest people you can work with. In a fast pace environment, interns are given the same responsibilities as full time employees - making you feel part of the team and contributing to the product. As an intern, not only do you get great experiences with other interns, but executives make time to interact with you and make sure you are invested in your few months as part of the company. This past summer was an internship I will never forget.
cons: It is really hard to think of any negative experiences I have had at SalesforceIQ. Maybe the only thing is as new employees (as they grow in numbers), invest more with meeting people across the company.

headline: Awesome company, beware of remote site politics
pros: Great company and vibes, perks are excellent, company has been steadily growing for the past 5 years. Product leadership know what they are doing, not afraid to scrap bad projects and spend money on good acquisitions.
cons: If you're not in San Francisco as an engineer or product manager you are far away from decisions and other options within the company.

headline: Fair at all
pros:
1. Free food Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Evening Snacks
2. Free beverages and snacks
3. Iphone and Macbook
4. Wellness reimbursement 
5. Internet reimbursement 
6. Stock options 
7. Patent bonus
8. Performance bonus
cons:
1. Pays less in accordance with same post in other firms
2. No joining bonus, salesforce doesn't have a culture of joining bonus
3. No company based cabs and even no reimbursement for daily travel
4. No gifts (atleast should give some gifts yearly or diwali)

headline: Great work/life balance and endless opportunities to learn
pros: 100 times bigger than any other place I've worked, and I still get to do things I enjoy at small companies, like pick frameworks and languages I want to develop, wfh when I need and want to (usually 2 days a week). But also have the perks of a huge company like benefits, salary, programs for all aspects of life.
cons: It's probably impossible to keep up with everything going on, and although it's possible, it's hard to figure out how to keep up with what you want to, like your areas of interest and work.  But there is the opportunity to through communication, videos, meetings, etc, to keep up with whatever you want.

headline: QA Engineer
pros: Team Collaboration, Learning how Scrum Teams run and learnt Agile Platform, CRM Essentials, Software Development Life Cycle. As a QA, learnt how automation framework would work and had good communication with Developers. Very Good experience in learning and delivering my skills at Salesforce
cons: No cons for the company but it is a Contract Role and I am interested in Full-Time

headline: Salesforce is awesome
pros:
Big company with start up feel
1-1-1 model is for real - company cares deeply about employees and community
cons: Sometimes feels like loosely organized chaos

headline: Company is becoming an Enterprise Software player
pros: Philanthropic model is outstanding. Some very nice people. If you are under 30, this is the place to work.
cons: Extreme example of hero culture. If you are coming from an acquisition and on Marc's radar - everything is possible. Until the next big shiny object comes along (next dreamforce). Not a good place to work for if you are above 45.

headline: Quiet content
pros: forward-thinking, proactive, innovative, open, welcoming, supportive
cons:
some changes can take quite a while to instantiate
plans are not always clearly communicated
while change is necessary anywhere, it can be detrimental to some

pros: Great culture, focused vision, excellent benefits, great growth opportunities, growing very fast, focus on customer success, high visibility company, technology that works
cons: Growing very fast, some industry focus seems unorganized and not led or driven by the best industry experts, employee development can be improved

headline: Great place to work
pros: Highly ethical and innovative company.  Our customers love the products we deliver.  There is a strong commitment to diversity and equality.
cons: The company is growing very quickly and that creates some challenges - but those challenges also provide opportunities for growth.

headline: Account Executive
pros:
Good career perspectives 
Fast enablement 
Very collaborative positions (win as a team)
cons: difficulties to change your geographical position

headline: Great place to work
pros: There are lots of good people. Overall the business is solid and we'll run. The compensation and benefits are fantastic.
cons: Like any large company, there is a fire drill culture and the politics are sometimes frustrating. It's sometimes very difficult to get anything done.

headline: Great Company
pros: Wonderful environment where you want to go in to work every day. They treat you like an adult and don't hover. Do what's expected of you and you're in a solid place. And you'll have plenty of opportunity to do new things that you've never done before.
cons: Still a massively growing company so there's some reorganization going on that complicates learning the minor details about Salesforce and the technologies it uses.

headline: Great Summer Internship
pros:
Specific To Interns: 

Interns are given a lot of resources to both learn and have fun. There are about 1-3 speaker series every week for interns as well as other tech talks which are open to all employees. There were also so many fun events to help interns explore San Francisco such as a cable car tour, a small cruise ride, or street food tours. 

Overall Company:

The company culture is fantastic. Salesforce is huge on doing social good and do a lot to help employees have a positive impact as well. For example, there is generous donation matching, hours of VTO (time off for volunteering,) and awards for employees who volunteer more. For example, the company has an internal Facebook-like system where posts are public to everyone and most communication / business is done on it.

Every 4 months, there's an internal career fair where you can learn about other teams' projects and transfer to another team if you'd like.
cons: It's a larger company so work tends to move more slowly. However, your actual team is usually small.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Great benefits for health and retirement
cons: Micromanagement atmosphere for sales. Culture is beginning to change into hard selling customers. Customer is taking back seat to Salesforce's growth plans

headline: Finance
pros: great mentorship! They spent the time trying to help me grow as an individual and were very helpful in introducing me to other teams
cons: hierarchical layers. Some projects were completed but did not have a big impact on the final decision making or impacted the firm in a big way.

headline: Senior account executive
pros: Great company to work for
cons: Lot of pressure and monthly targets

headline: Whatever
pros: Fast paced company with a lot of talented people
cons: Monthly targets and a lot of pressure

headline: Depends on role
pros:
- Employee perks, almost no one cares if you work from home ever, as long as you get your job done
- Smartest people to work with in the industry
- Values drive and innovation
cons:
- Getting big and unwieldy so all the innovation can get a bit chaotic
- Politics at HQ, better in satellite offices
-

headline: Product Marketing Intern
pros: Management is amazing, Great benefits,
cons: This isn't really a negative but be prepared to work hard and learn a lot. You are surrounded by some of the top students across the nation along with some of the smartest managers. It's a competitive company to get into. If you expect the best of yourself then you're in the right place.

headline: Software Engineering Internship
pros:
An amazing summer full of learning, fun, and hard work. The FutureForce team does an amazing job filling the summer with fun experiences (party on a boat, renting out all of SOMA Streatfood Park, a baseball game, and so much more) as well as learning experiences. We had lunch and learns from executives like the CFO, CEO of Heroku, and tons of thought leaders. What's really great about all of these experiences though is that it's clear the fun and learning is not just an opportunity for interns but for full time employees too. Throughout the summer, there was an all Tech and Product summer picnic at the zoo with included animal adventures and an amazing barbecue, a Summer of 99 party, and tons of lunch and learns with internal and external people presenting research. 

On my team I was able to contribute to features and bugs and was challenged and stretched but supported the whole time. I was able to demo to high level executives and definitely contribute real value. 

Another really unique aspect of Salesforce is their commitment to Ohana, or family. All of the employees, customers, and partners are treated with the highest level of respect. I especially appreciated the commitment to increasing diversity in the tech industry. One way Salesforce aims to do this is through the employee resource groups, like FemmeForce, BOLD, OutForce, and LatinoForce. Another way Salesforce aims to help the community is through volunteering. Every employee gets 56 hours to volunteer and we as interns were able to spend up to 56 hours volunteering as well! I was able to volunteer at an urban farm, a beach cleanup, and much more!
cons: There really aren't any downsides. All of my expectations leading up to the internship were exceeded.

headline: Mismanagement since Salesforce acquision
pros:
- It WAS  a great place to work for.
- Regular Salesforce benefits.
cons:
- Poor (micro) management at work place.
- Compensation not on par with that of Salesforce employees, but they expect us to work extra hours.
- Nobody cares about what you want or say anymore. It's all about saving their name with Salesforce.

A lot of freedom given and job is interesting

cons:

Stressfull at time esp end of quarter

headline: 3 Years in
