headline: Business Development Representative @ Salesforce
pros: Great company culture, excellent atmosphere, personal autonomy, fantastic benefits
cons: Some alignment issues regarding verticals in a Sales environment, occasional communication difficulties around goals between virtual teams and internal.

headline: Love working here!
pros: Love the work culture here. Since there are no stack rankings, your coworkers are not adversaries. People genuinely want to help each other and are recognized for it. Great work life balance and an open work environment.
cons: Things change really fast here. One moment you are working on something and the next you will be working on something else. Some accumulated technical debt as the company is growing way too fast. Benefits are slightly below average compared to the other big names.

headline: Aloha
pros: Collaborative, Smart people that like to do great work and have fun doing it
cons: Change happens a lot and can be frustrating

headline: Dev
pros:
Very good benefits provided by company.
Good culture
Good work environment
cons: Fast paced environments and very tight deadlines.

headline: Best job ever
pros: Benefits, office, location, people, industry
cons: There were no cons with this employer.

headline: Cheap company
pros: Nothing good about this company
cons: These guys are into slavery. They hire people at 22 dollars an hour!!!!!!!!!!!!

headline: Decent culture, good benefits.
pros: Many good people to reinforce good culture. Rich of benefits.
cons: It's ill luck of me to be in a wrong team and have a management which enforce me to over work, e.g. 18 hr a day to satisfy her. Can't bear that pressure so long and finally goodbye.

headline: Salesforce.com
pros:
1. Flexible
2. Merit Based
3. Fast Paced
cons: 1. Lack of Work Life Balance

headline: Account Executive
pros: I've been working at salesforce for the past 3 years and it's the best career decision I have ever made. I've learned more about business, technology and myself in the last 3 years of being here than in my entire career. The technology here really works and it's rewarding to see the positive impact you can make on a company!
cons: It is a high energy, fast paced, demanding sales environment. You need to force yourself to have a  healthy work/life balance.

headline: High Performance, positive environment
pros: Positive, can-do attitude amongst employees and management. The company is invested in retaining and up skilling staff.
cons: Fast paced company, employees work hard to stay certified, up to date with platform releases and industry trends.

headline: Salesforce is a great place to work
pros: You get to work with great people, for leadership that cares about more than just money, and there are a ton of little perks that add up to make one of the best work environments I've experienced.
cons: Sometime the speed of the bureaucracy can be frustrating.

headline: Intern
pros: Incredible work environment, friendly employees that are always willing to teach.  Great working culture and shared company values.
cons: Not all areas of the company are growing at the same rate

headline: Sales representitive
pros: Great work atmosphere, very competitive but learn a lot. Would recommend working there to start a sales career. You can come in from any level and work your way up
cons: Career progression is not as good as it is suggested. However given that you get brilliant training for each position and a lot of experience it is worth it . Management are very supportive but very much focused on activity, if you are more of a relationship building person and take time closing deals I wouldn't recommend it as it is more high activity driven

headline: Marketing
pros: great people (in fact, I'm friends with many of them outside of my professional life), fast paced, innovative and good compensation
cons: At the end of the day, Salesforce is a software company, not a technology company. The senior people they hire are all from ex-Oracle, Adobe and that type of culture cascades down. Lots of red tape and people getting promotion that didn't deserve it so I left.

headline: Great
pros: Nice working culture and healthy competition.
cons: Not a good place to work if you want to live lavishly without any work.

headline: Honest Truth
pros:
-Working with extremely talented individuals
-Love the team and company culture
-Great support system
-Immediate management is always open to new ideas and easy to talk with
-Fast paced (also rough at times) 
-Access to other career paths within company if desired
cons:
-Although I love the company culture of giving back and always pushing harder and faster, it can ware you down if your not careful. Pacing yourself is very important. 
-Upper management (VP and above) mean well but manages to make the team nervous and work off of fear of being made to look bad in front of the entire department.
-Recruiters often have a tough time working with our support (Keeping in mind that sourcing support is something a lot of recruiters don't have experience with before coming to Salesforce)

headline: Great Place to Work.  Many Opportunities.
pros:
- Great culture
- Very energetic
- Lots of perks
- Free beer at work
- Many investment options: 401k, Employee Stock Purchase
cons: - Organizational change is difficult.  Everything changes every month on the Marketing Cloud Support team.  This will calm down as the Marketing Cloud assimilates further into Salesforce practices.

headline: Being recognized as innovative (every year), is a tough track record
pros: Strong vision, strong culture, every year have to create a new form of sliced bread.
cons: Hard to finish what was started from year to year.

headline: Business Decelopment Rep
pros: Fun enviornment, great training program, approachable managers, ability to grow within the company.
cons: commison should be based off your current book of business vs being the same for everyone on the team.

headline: Training Account Executive
pros: There is a focus on work/life balance - that making your number is your priority but it's expected that you do this in an independent, mature way.
cons: Growing region means (too) many hats to wear in addition to base responsibilities without a lot of foresight or managerial support.

headline: The most organized company that prepares all employees and Clients for success.
pros:
Best employee on boarding I have seen in my 30 years in this business. 
Great coaching and offers of assistance from all levels of leadership. 
An excellent opportunity to continue to learn in a fast paced, fun environment. 
A product/platform that is easy to be passionate about. 
Use what you sell and sell what you use
cons: Wish I had come here earlier in my career.  A great environment. I would recommend Salesforce to anyone with a passion and desire for success.

headline: Salesforce
pros: Salesforce has an amazing benefits package which includes a competitive salary, volunteer opportunities, wellness plan, and many other great perks.
cons: None that I can think of!

headline: Great Values - Poor Growth
pros: Incredible values, incredible character. Salesforce is a company with ethics and it shows
cons:
Strong emphasis on management training, poor execution. 
HR Issues go un-answered

headline: Resume Cornerstone
pros:
*Vibrant office culture
*One-of-a-kind corporate commitment to community/philanthropic impact
*Business acumen & makeup of sales talent is excellent on the whole
*Salesforce is a very powerful logo on any resume
*The company is a cross-selling machine. Understanding the breadth of solutions available to sell - and doing it - is a tremendous opportunity for development
*Fantastic future outlook for the business. Take advantage of the ESPP program!
cons:
*Highest performers in the commercial space seem to be most adept at structuring contracts - not necessarily at creating business impact for customers. This feels like a symptom of the Oracle influx in recent years
*The mega-growth is great, but the growth necessitates faster promotions and shrinking territories. This creates a unique burden on often inexperienced management to evaluate sales talent subjectively. Subjective decisions on promotions and territory carving - even when correct - often creates discontent among individual contributors who believe they've been evaluated unfairly.
*Promotions happen quickly, and therefore require individual contributors and even first line managers to spend more time managing internal politics than delivering value to customers.
*Commercial customers often have 2-3 different AE's (account managers) per year, which can make it difficult to establish a relationship. The result is that even great customers view Salesforce as a vendor instead of a partner in their growth.
*Selling into the enterprise space is exciting at Salesforce, but sales talent turnover is staggering.

headline: Great ethos hurt by untrained middle management
pros:
Great technical opportunities
Lots of ways to volunteer and give back
Comfortable working environment
cons:
Easy to get caught in a turf war
Managers promoted from technical staff - some try and solve people problems as if it were a coding exercise
Product is a specific tool generalized to a platform

headline: Intern
pros: Awesome people, awesome mission, and great opportunities
cons: It is extremely difficult to get in

headline: Account Executive
pros: Great Culture, Great Products and amazing resources
cons: Management treats employees like we work in a call center. Very tactical thinking

headline: Love this place!
pros: Salesforce is driven for all the right reasons - high quality products, successful customers and employees and giving back. It's exciting to see things 'actually' change based on innovation and strategy to ensure our 2020 vision!
cons: It's constantly changing, which in my mind is important to stay fresh and relevant. It can sometimes be a challenge though.

headline: Best Company I've ever worked for
pros: The products are excellent, the people are smart, collaborative and hardworking.  The CEO is a visionary, the best marketer in technology, and exceedingly generous and caring, backed up with actions not just words.   Customers are treated with respect and the company truly cares about their success.
cons: The company continues to grow like crazy and that comes with well known challenges.   With all that craziness though, comes tremendous opportunity.

headline: Talent manager
pros: Very pro-active environment. Very positive people
cons: Can move a little too fast

headline: It really does have the best culture
pros:
- creativity is celebrated
- the perks (like Dreamforce)
- work with brilliant colleagues who elevate you
- a company that really lives its values
cons:
- bluntness
- decentralized employee comms leads to some mixed messaging
- trying to keep up with its own growth

headline: A culture of caring
pros:
The company has a culture that fosters a social, perhaps family-like experience.  The people that you encounter seem to take a genuine interest and have made time to help.  They are a growth company and very successful in that space and that helps with morale -- people like being with a winner.

The benefits, I found, are very good.  It's great where you know that stuff is taken care of and you can focus on getting the customers to where they want to go.  There are even extras that show the company is actually concerned about their employees well-being, not just normal medical health.
cons: The company is going through some intense growth right now and, as a result, you can tell that some are overwhelmed.  There are many processes in place, but even they are showing some stress from the rate.  While this isn't a deal-breaker, some patience is usually all that is required and the issues do get resolved.

headline: Incredible company
pros: Intelligent staff, welcoming and inclusive culture, meaningful philanthropic commitment, strong business fundamentals, competitive compensation and robust benefits with a focus on internal growth and development
cons: None so far other than a lack of on-site parking but there are generous commuter reimbursements for using public transit.

headline: Growth and Change
pros: Career potential, Company growth, Top talent, Foundation activities
cons: Pace of growth can lead to processes breaking

headline: Awesome Place for a techy
pros:
great work life balance
downtown offices are amazing
cons: nothing worth writing down......its not ET but it is still Salesforce

headline: Technical Staff
pros: One of the Fortune's 100 best companies to work for. Perfect Work life balance.
cons: I don't see any cons. Its a great company to work for. Good benefits plans, Stock options, Casual working environment

headline: Management
pros:
Fantastic Energy
Clear vision of the Strategy
cons: Ability to work under pressure

headline: Best employeer - life changing experience!
pros: Amazing team here in Dublin EMEA HQ. I joined SFDC in Feb 2015 and was amazed since first days about the culture - Senior VP (Sanj) greeted me personally - that never ever happened in my 10+ years in IT. The team helped me to achieve my annual target in just 8 months. I thought I have nothing to learn, but I realized I was wrong - so many hints & tips which helped me to became even better sales person. Looking forward to develop myself during many years with SFDC.
cons: There are no Cons ! Salesforce is not a corporation - it is one big family, which is really CUSTOMER FOCUSED !

headline: Taught high school kids Spanish
pros: Love to be able to help and facilitate their learning progress. Focused mainly on their listening skills and correct way to pronounce the words .
cons: The pace at which the lessons move seemed so fast. More time should be spent on listening and speaking skills.

headline: Great place!
pros: The people are very high quality, interesting, smart, talented, driven and supportive.
cons: Pay is less than what industry standards would be.

headline: Finally found my #dreamjob!!!
pros:
- Overall great company, brand, products, culture
- Work Life balance is amazing 
- The people I work with are like family AND they are smart and productive
- Volunteer Time Off
- Work hard play hard is a reality here
cons:
This is not really a con but could be a con if you are not an A player or used to being in a fast paced environment - We work at a very fast pace, heavily metrics oriented and with a high sense of urgency.  I love it but not everyone likes or is accustomed to this type of environment.  

Unless you are in HQ you may hit a ceiling with your career growth.

headline: Thrilling, fast-paced, hard work
pros: Salesforce is growing at an amazing pace. The culture is fantastic in certain parts of the org. The technology is innovative and always changing. This is the place for you if you can take initiative, work hard, and grow/change with the company
cons: the pace of work is hard. you need to be ready for it

headline: Most Innovative Enterprise Software Company
pros: Great People, Fast Paced Innovation, Amazing Technology, Competent Workforce, Charity is at core of company values
cons: opportunities for growth unclear, training ramp up is slightly haphazard

headline: Unsung Hero
pros:
Marc is amazing - innovative, out of the box thinking, pushes our thinking outside the boundaries
Focus on women in leadership
Generous with employees (concerts, etc)
One of the best companies to work for in SF
Brand is strong and growing - pride to work here
cons:
Not enough SE's - we are leaving business on the table
Long hours/not enough people in the right roles
Lots of back office duplication - - leaders not willing to make tough choices
Only execs get cars - not the doers

headline: Fast-paced with pressure to succeed, but rewarding
pros:
-Salesforce has dozens of products designed to solve specific problems, so you get the chance to help customers sort through their issues and solve a variety of problems. 
-Work-life balance is good
-Still tons of room for growth and big earnings. 
-Great team atmosphere with lots of events. 1:1:1 model means you get to volunteer with your team members regularly.
cons: -End of month and end of quarter is incredibly busy and there is a lot of pressure to exceed targets in last week of a period.

headline: Great company to work for, going through growing pains
pros: Good benefits, great culture, with an emphasis on giving back to charity. Good work life balance and time off benefits / parental leave
cons: Going through a big of a growth spurt and feeling growing pains along the way. If you're not in SF office, it can feel like you don't exist at times.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Fast growing company. Incredible products and very smart people
cons: Culture is changing to be too churn and burn.  Feels like SF.com is becoming Oracle

headline: Slow career path at HQ
pros: Money is good,  lots of products to sell, high Customer  sat and philanthropy makes me proud to say I work here.  Tremendous resources available and easy to find people to help you on deals
cons: Not exactly a meritocracy,  the self promoting bro's get the promos.  More upward mobility available in other locations not in San Francisco.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Fast growing company. Incredible products and very smart people
cons: Culture is changing to be too churn and burn.  Feels like SF.com is becoming Oracle

headline: Slow career path at HQ
pros: Money is good,  lots of products to sell, high Customer  sat and philanthropy makes me proud to say I work here.  Tremendous resources available and easy to find people to help you on deals
cons: Not exactly a meritocracy,  the self promoting bro's get the promos.  More upward mobility available in other locations not in San Francisco.

headline: Great Company to work for
pros: project opportunities, work life balance, benefits
cons: all things are very satisfying but free lunch would be good.... amount of rsu grant is very small..

headline: Sr. Technical Recruiter
pros:
- The people, the energy, the continued learning, wellness and awesome leaders/ products and culture ...

- Being able to volunteer 48 hours a year and gain grants to charities I care about personally.
cons: - We don't get free lunches like Google but we did get most diverse workplace ... so you win some, you lose some.

headline: Great learning experience
pros: Great work environment. Very smart folks and a lot of room to grow whithin the company
cons: Need more entrepreneurial projects that will push innovation

headline: Senior Software Dev
pros: Great office space, smart co-workers.  Great benefits and perks (company parties, team outings, etc).  Simply put, you get treated like a rock star
cons: Very HQ-centric culture, remote employees/offices don't get as much attention.  Code base is very long in the tooth and can be hard to work with

headline: good culture
pros: super culture, good top talented people, super onboarding training bootcamp
cons: bad line management in some area

headline: Program Manager
pros:
Freedom to execute beyond your given role - if there's technology, tools, etc out there that you feel passionate about exploring, all I get are green lights! 

Support from manager.

Work IN the city - no commute! 

Incredibly passionate CEO who in the 5 years I've been at Salesforce where I've watched us grow from 5K to 20K employees, he STILL replies to personal emails from employees. He's amazing. His enthusiasm  is infectious. And his philanthropic passion is admirable. 

Flexible work environment - easy to WFH if necessary without feeling like you're missing out. 

Camaraderie among team and company - on a global scale. 

Travel - just recently I was asked to go to Japan. Incredible experience immersing myself into our office there and really getting to know the culture and people who up until then, was all conducted remotely. Total game changer when given the opportunity to sit down face to face!!
cons:
Staying informed among the management chain changes. Lots of movement - all good things but definitely not doing a great job communicating those changes to employees first. I'm fortunate because I work in a department privy to that info, but to speak on  behalf of other departments not close to HR, I know they feel lost and surprised too often. Many times creating unnecessary scares causing folks to prematurely jump ship - most boomerang back but k feel if we could get in front of this, we could reduce the boomerang rate. 

Additionally, RSU and overall stock grants to a limited number of employees. At my former employer, I was given RSUs off the bat but not here at SFDC and I've been here almost 5 years and in a fairly senior role. Not sure why that's the case. Colleagues feel the same and those good friends of mine who got stock are shocked I have none. Seems like a basic perk but it's not given to everyone :(

headline: Great place to grow
pros: This is a company that recognizes and rewards smart people and collaboration.  You don't have to have a title to have a voice.  Open doors to all levels of leadership and support for taking on roles that are more than just the next step in your function.  Come here to grow, learn and earn!
cons: Pace is real, not measured in hours but in timeliness to make decisions.

headline: AE
pros: love the job, super challenging, co-workers are great
cons: overly competitive, but still a great thing. Potential hostile coworkers, but minor

headline: HRIS
pros: Collaborative and good work environment.  Nice team feeling.
cons: Management needs to focus on growth

headline: Top-notch employer in our region
pros: Salesforce has a great work atmosphere, fantastic benefits and competitive pay compared to their competitors.
cons: Depending on the department you work in, some of the management staff do not seem to fully grasp their own positions, and it makes it difficult for the people they are supposed to be managing

headline: Senior Release Manager
pros:
Skilled, friendly people in a very fast paced environment
Great opportunities to grow and explore within the company
cons:
Too many changes all the time
People, teams change directions very often and sometimes that can be frustrating

headline: Challenging Innovative company that is hard to leave
pros: Great, people, benefits and opportunities to develop yourself and career in new ways.
cons: Repetitive, Very Sales focused and challenging meeting high expectations of the role.

headline: Salesforce
pros: Great people, fast moving environment, good benefits.
cons: Management very rigid not willing to allow employees to shape their own careers.  Upper level management often fails to understand the work that is being done because they are too far removed.

headline: Losing its luster to typical corporate BS
pros: Compensation, location, legit commitment to philanthropy. Lots of friendly people. Dreamforce is unique. Stock keeps going up. Lots of free booze everywhere if that's your thing.
cons: Lipstick on a pig: Salesforce is the fun, friendly corporation but it's still a corporation. Most of the leaders rose to the top bc they're sociopaths who embraced the corporate game - just like at any other big Corp. politics trump innovation. Things move slowly. The tech is outdated. The website is horrible.

headline: Incredible Place to Work
pros: Amazing company filled with brilliant minds. Everyone is incredibly down to earth. The company's values stem from the 1-1-1 model of giving back which is felt in the day to day work and culture.
cons: Sometimes long hours, but the people make it worth it.

headline: New at Salesforce
pros: Premises are great, environment is good, people are smart, product sounds interesting, engagement are challenging, income is adequate, lots of other advantages, foundation spirit
cons: No real experience in advisory, building it up right now so can be challenging to work there, very technical background required, have to pass a lot of certifications that are not necessarily aligned to the type of job

headline: Account Executive
pros: The new hire process was great and, being with Salesforce is amazing.
cons: It is definitely overwhelming but, that's the only con.

headline: Tier II Analyst
pros: Great atmosphere, work hard play hard
cons: Can get very stressful especially early on learning everything.

headline: Tier II Analyst
pros: Great atmosphere, work hard play hard
cons: Can get very stressful especially early on learning everything.

headline: The Sales Career Jackpot
pros: I wasn't actively looking for another career when Salesforce recruiters approached me on LinkedIn, but I am so glad they did.  Salesforce hires extremely talented, ambitious, and laser-smart people, and I've learned more here in 6 months than I have in the last several years.  The salary is excellent, benefits unparalleled, and the culture is one of generosity and giving back (volunteer hours are highly encouraged and employees can take time off work, with pay, to give back to their communities locally and globally).
cons: The pace is very fast.  There is a lot of travel and sometimes little guidance, Salesforce hires smart people and expects them to dive in the deep end and not only to swim..but to win the race and to coach the rest of the pack while doing it.  I wouldn't necessarily classify this as a con personally though - I like the moving fast, and learning and innovating on a daily basis.

headline: AE
pros: Very innovative and very fast-paced!
cons: Hard to say ... lots of info and ways to learn but sometimes locating key data is hard.

headline: Lives up to the promise
pros: Great culture. Very inclusive and supportive. Growth driven. Every employee has a personal plan on how the contribute to overall business (V2MOM), bonus are realistic and achievable. They celebrate success and encourage giving back to the community through the 1:1:1 foundation work. Heavily invested in innovation.
cons: Not many I've found so far. Depending on your role you may have to travel a bit. As its getting bigger you need to spend some time studying the org chart to work out who to contact to push some things along.

headline: Amazing company to work for!
pros: The revolutinary SaaS CRM company on the market with clear vision and strong leadership from Marc Benioff that will change our future forever.
cons: Based on my personal and professional experience there are no cons that I can speak about.

headline: Worst Management
pros: Company Culture is good. I enjoy my flexible schedule to allow a healthy work life balance
cons: The company is growing very rapidly, still because of the management issue employees has to suffer

headline: Great place to work, expectations are high
pros: Aloha spirit makes it great place to work. It's challenging environment - we work with the best.
cons: Compensation could be better, in Dublin it's below industry average

headline: Excited to Start
pros: Havent started yet, but during internship the team was very helpful and wants to see you grow.
cons: None have come up so far.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great place to work at!
cons: Too much traffic downtown SF

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
Very flexible working hours. 
Many new projects you can work on
cons: Sometimes the amount of trust work will distract you from building new feature

headline: Love working at Salesforce
pros: I get a lot of autonomy to run my business and drive my own success. Many career growth opportunities.
cons: Many days and weeks of long hours. Our group is greatly understaffed.

headline: Great company
pros: Salesforce is visionary. They are literally defining the market.  It's a fun, high energy, fast paced environment.  The focus on the customer and customer success is out of this world...  It's great to work at a company where customers love the product more than the company does.  And importantly, the company has a soul - with integrated philanthropy and volunteering.
cons: The company is growing fast and needs to invest in training for new people and systems and processes as it grows.  Work/life balance is up to you to manage - you can do it, but you have to own it.

headline: Microsoft invades infrastructure engineering
pros: Great location, competitive pay, great benefits, excellent culture of giving back through the salesforce foundation (1-1-1 culture).
cons: There is corporate culture and there's departmental culture. The corporate culture at salesforce.com is still one of the best in the industry but the influx of Microsoft employees (particularly leadership positions)  in Infrastructure Engineering under Randy Kern and Ed Harris have promoted an extremely top-down culture which is the antithesis of what Marc Benioff and Parker Harris stand for. This has resulted in a high-level of attrition which has left the infrastructure team limping along, unable to attract top talent and unable to make demonstrable progress towards a long-term roadmap.

headline: Good people doing great work while having fun
pros: Great pay and benefits (employee stock purchase plan, wellness allowance and fitness centers, snacks). The company really cares about employee well-being, work-life balance, gender diversity, giving back, and doing the right thing, so I feel good about spending a third of my weekday hours at work. Stock is up, company is still growing, etc. It feels great to be the winning team.
cons: Not much to say here, except that it is a large company (17,000 employees and growing) which may not be for everybody. Things still move very fast for a company of this size though!

headline: Great company
pros:
Work life balance
Not for profit work
Great offices and working environment 
Good pay
cons: I really don't have anything negative to say. It's a fast growing dynamic company and it's great place to work.

headline: LMTS
pros: Good Work - Life Balance

headline: Best Job Ever
pros: I joined Salesforce about 5 years ago. Never looked back. Love the company culture and that they really care about their employees. Plenty of opportunities to grow and switch up what you're working on. Upper management is transparent and shares where they are taking the company and why.
cons: Pretty fast paced environment. I love it, but it's not for people who just want to coast along. Company has been growing really fast and office space is pretty tight.

headline: Great Company, amazing CEO
pros: Incredible performance and culture! love the fight spirit, amazing products and R&D teams working with a strong focus on business.
cons: Intermediate management is not always efficient and smart enough!

headline: Great Company

headline: CBU Sales, ESMB

headline: Great place to work
pros: I spent 4 1/2 years at Salesforce.   Marc has created an amazing company culture that encourages employee feedback and diversity.  Very proud that I worked at Salesforce.

headline: VP

headline: good comp & nice perks but carefully consider working style and cultural fit
pros:
good lateral & promotional opportunities. good salary. good benefits choices (but not cheap, say $350-700/mo employee portion for heath/life/eye/dental for a family plan). good perks (wellness & phone benefits, partner discounts). potential remote working opportunities

many business partners & acquisitions & big Dreamforce conference for even more networking options. sharp, quick-minded people. puts its salespeople first (surprise!)
cons:
fast pace leaves the human factor behind. in a fast-changing business, work often gets discarded. mgmt get ahead of themselves, projects move too fast, creating waste, repetition, and loss of morale. 

shallow creative mindset, more about getting things done regardless of aesthetics. 

mgmt employs traditional project mgmt ways, shows fear/avoidance in interfacing with subordinates, and fails to treat people as company values aspire. shallowness, fakeness, and passive aggressiveness abounds. ok environ for juniors who want a happy ra-ra culture at the expense of being surrounded by people who show they genuinely care about your well being.

headline: One of my favorite jobs!

cons: there was nothing significant to note

headline: A kind and caring work environment

cons: Large company, with the processes and amount of job titles it implies. Overwhelming amount of information scattered across a lot of systems.

headline: Terrific Company

cons: Haven't come across any negatives thus far. Seems like the they've done a terrific job of laying the foundation for a healthy and supportive, although competitive, working environment.

pros: The energy and innovation is unparalleled in industry.

headline: Great company to learn how to become a world class product manager
pros:
Best job I've had as a product manager. At Salesforce, depending on your cloud, you have the opportunity to do everything that got you wanting to be a product manager in the first place. Incredible customer interactions ranging from 1-on-1s to Dreamforce presentations. Deep technical conversations with your engineering teams. Creative discussions with the UX organizations. And the best product demos you'll ever create.

For a large company, things move fast here, and that keeps things fresh.
cons: With a large organization, there will be people who slip through the cracks of quality. For example, sometimes good people leave to purse other projects they're interested in, leaving an opening for less talented people below to slot themselves in. This can disappoint other members of the team, but you just have to stay focused and do quality work yourself. People know who the good ones are.

headline: Success Analyst Tier II
pros: Great work environment.  Very easy to collaborate with colleagues.  Easy to track case from beginning to end.
cons: You need to close a certain number of cases, but some cases are much more difficult than others to close and the productivity formula does not take that into account.

headline: Sr. Director

headline: SE Manager
pros: What is advertised about taking care of employees is true.  The technology is amazing and can run an enterprise.

headline: Great opportunities

- Growth driven
- Great culture

headline: Account Executive
pros: Product sells itself. Great pay, benefits, and stock plan make it comfortable to work / life in San Francisco. Amazing work life balance, never at the office past 5 pm.
cons: Management is rarely happy even when you close a big deal because they want you selling all of the products even when it doesnt make sense for the customer. They push product down customer's throats even though they call themselves a 'customer company.' Every month feels like it's end of quarter or end of year and managers care more about following the sales playbook versus helping you close the deal.

headline: New

headline: Drinking water out of a firehose

cons: The culture is lackluster and very fratty! The amount of information and knowledge is challenging. I felt like being on an island and everyone on the team is in it for themselves.

headline: salesforce review
pros: interesting work, great co-workers, nice perks, good work-life balance, flexibility, no crazy hours
cons: can be a very political landscape. it is a boys' club and you have to fit in to advance

headline: Gone from Great to Good to Poor in 1 year
pros:
Good pay
Great benefits
Well respected in the community
SOME absolutely amazing people (diminishing as we speak)
cons:
When I first joined this company 2 years ago, it was full of passionate people who cared about the company, the products, and most importantly, each other.  Employee success was paramount to company success, and we had a leadership team that recognized that.

Now, with the infiltration of Salesforce (which, don't get me wrong, Salesforce is great in its own way, but that greatness has not manifested in Indianapolis - it's been mostly destructive), the Marketing Cloud leadership team is much more concerned with making people like Marc Benioff and Alex Dayyon happy rather than creating a culture of happy employees.  In a recent "V2MOM" session, leadership blatantly voted "employee success" as the LEAST important value among 6-7 value options.  Don't you get it?  Happy and successful employees lead to good product, good service, and thriving business!!

As I look around, I see a bunch of people sitting there just doing bare minimum to collect a paycheck, others frantically trying to cling to the last bit of Orange culture they can find, and a select few who thrive in this new environment of "nothing matters but the bottom line".  I'm sure that the short term business outlook will be great, as Salesforce manages to squeeze the last bit of quality work out of employees, but if this keeps up, there's no long term to speak of.

headline: Great Company
pros: Model was a great company to work for.  Great office culture and lots of respect in the marketplace.
cons: Selling the organization to Salesforce made sense but changed the opportunities within the organization.

headline: Salesforce Marketing Cloud
pros: Good pay & benefits including pension, gym, healthcare etc etc.
cons: Quite cut throat, with blame culture throughout business.  If a deal is lost everyone is trying to find someone to blame rather than accept that the product(s) have not been innovative enough.  Marketing is great but in reality much of what you see at Dreamforce does not exist.

headline: Salesforce Marketing Cloud
pros: Good pay & benefits including pension, gym, healthcare etc etc.
cons: Quite cut throat, with blame culture throughout business.  If a deal is lost everyone is trying to find someone to blame rather than accept that the product(s) have not been innovative enough.  Marketing is great but in reality much of what you see at Dreamforce does not exist.

headline: Unreal
pros: SF takes care of their employees and provides support to achieve goals.  Culture is amazing and people and leadership is unlike any other place I have worked.

headline: Dipping my toe into client side
pros: Great company that takes care of you and really wants you to succeed. They understand that creative people are coming from ad agencies and its really different. They are super supportive and want you to learn.
cons: Very different from the ad agency model. Difficult on-boarding. Sometimes the sheer size of the company gets in its own way.

headline: Grass is greener...
pros: One of the few companies where the upper management really shows that they are thinking about and want to see their employees succeed.  One of the very best companies I have ever worked for.

IT development can be dis-organized at times.  Focusing at times was very difficult.  No clear direction provided by IT management.
***Really difficult*** to move from "IT" to "R&D".  R&D in general has a very arrogant/Superiority complex.   It feels like most in R&D tell themselves that "no one can do what they are doing."  That is not always the case!

headline: Good place to be overall

Brand name
Great people
Potential to make real money

Small territories, 10 accounts
Politics
Oraclization happening

headline: My experience at salesforce
pros:
amazing perks, including gym reimbursements, stacked snack bar, pool and fuss ball table, 
competitive salaries and bonuses, nice people
cons: slightly disorganised management structures, depending on which department you work in, not a lot of stimulating tasks, if you are ecologically inclined you'll find that the company is quite wasteful with hardware that has virtually not been used

headline: Growing Company with few Career Tracks Internally

headline: Great company culture, competitive environment

headline: Lives up to its promises

headline: Good company but a very cliquish culture
pros: Good company and CEO, Great Marketing Organization, Good products that need help, Great benefits..
cons:
- Very self centered organization typical of marketing and sales. People find every opportunity to promote themselves shamelessly.. That kind of stuff is encouraged..
- Very ordinary Sales Leadership. No idea of what it is to sell to Enterprise. still works as if its selling widgets to mom and pop shop..
Very much a Sales and Marketing company that does not like a contrarian viewpoint. If you come from a Engineering or Technology organizations, its a huge challenge to even have a conversation..
Products are good but long on the tooth..

headline: Sales rep

headline: Salary Review
pros: Great work and staff atmosphere
cons: They should offer better salaries and better benefits.

headline: Great internship/ $/ Team
pros: After doing their Toronto BizAcademy program, I interviewed for and got a great CSR internship/$15/hr pay/Team experience in my first semester in 2011 university). Nice people and free snacks at this top IT company. Three years later, I graduated and started working as an IT Recruiter at an agency.
cons: None in my 2 months internship there.

headline: Some good, some bad...
pros: Salesforce Marketing Cloud: good organisation overall, innovative products, great vision; and very professional and friendly colleagues
cons: From the Professional Services Department point of view, there is a lack of opportunities for internal promotions as the management seems to prefer hiring externally most of the time rather than giving a chance to employees that have been developing very hard themselves for the next opportunity; lack of support for professional development with a significant slow down in investing in external trainings and certifications; a lack of transparency towards the consultants that get updated at the last minute about internal changes; quite some room for improvement with regards to resource management as consultants are unclear on what they are meant to be working a week ahead or in terms of priorities and are demanded to do the extra mile every mile; and finally buggy new products that take several years to get almost fixed

headline: Great company, Great People
pros:
- Cutting edge technology
- Great benefits
- Responsive teams
- talented people
cons: can not think of any

headline: Doing it the right way
pros:
I know not all middle managers at Salesforce are like this, but my manager really puts his employees first. There's a lot of trust in employees to do the right thing, which means greater trust for things like work-life balance, work from home, etc. 

The top leaders really do care about the things they talk about as well which is great.
cons: I can't say there's much at this point.

headline: Love this place
pros: The benefits are awesome. The environment and culture are enough to want to make you stay for life. Free snacks, flexibility, the perks never stop.
cons: As the company grows, the corporate ladder becomes difficult to navigate. Sometimes it's hard to create new roles or explore career options as roles become set in a certain pattern.

headline: Love this place
pros: The benefits are awesome. The environment and culture are enough to want to make you stay for life. Free snacks, flexibility, the perks never stop.
cons: As the company grows, the corporate ladder becomes difficult to navigate. Sometimes it's hard to create new roles or explore career options as roles become set in a certain pattern.

headline: Amazing opportunity for Career Growth
pros: This company is growing dramatically.  The harder you work, the more opportunities that become available.  There's a defined career structure and the vision of the company is going to ensure that there is continued growth for the foreseeable future.
cons: This is not a company you can coast at.  It is filled with A players, so if you're looking for an easy ride, this isn't it.

headline: Salesforce
pros: Salesforce is a true 'do-ocracy', with an emphasis on delivering results. Tons of challenges and the opportunity to work with many truly smart people on difficult problems. Great working environment, good benefits.
cons: In some ways, the advantages are also its disadvantages - because of the 'do-ocracy' style, you can't rely on rank or title to have influence, especially when it comes to getting things done across silos. You not only have to have the best ideas, but you need to communicate them effectively in order to be successful. This can be difficult for people who rely on rank rather than indirect influence.

headline: Summer Intern
pros: Free snacks, awesome office building
cons: None, it was a good internship experience. I applied through FutureForce.

headline: Great company
pros: The technology, company culture, and the investment made to employees can;t be beat.
cons: Every company has cons, but the pro's to working at Salesforce outweigh the downsides.

headline: Awesome internship program, but growth is a little bit crazy
pros:
Intern housing downtown San Francisco & Indy
Snacks, beer at work
Frequent happy hours
Fun team outings
Fantastic company culture- very engaged with local community
cons: The company is reaching the point where it could really be considered a large company, rather than a medium one. As such, there are definitely some growing pains. Getting things like tickets resolved can take a long period of time, and there does seem to be some bloat. It's still a fantastic place to work, but does need to reevaluate as it grows.

headline: I LOVE THIS COMPANY!
pros: The people and environment are great
cons: Sometimes not 40 hour weeks

headline: Outstanding Place to Work
pros: I have worked at several of the major software firms in the Seattle area in my career. Salesforce by far has the greatest culture. There is a lot of energy and passion you can feel in the air. The company treats people right. There is no emphasis on constant evaluation like you see at companies like Microsoft and Amazon. The result is that the employees are self-motivated to be productive and innovative and collaborative. Benefits are excellent, including receiving pay for volunteer work you do for nonprofits. They match donations you make, even those to your local church or synagogue.
cons: - The CEO and company are very outspoken in support of progressive causes. If you are politically a right-wing conservative, you may feel uncomfortable.

headline: Senior Account Executive
pros: Great culture, products, people, pay and benefits. And it is great to work for a company that places giving back among the high priorities.
cons: Difficult to move up or across functions due to the massive scale of external hiring. The startup culture is fading with scale.

headline: Analyst
pros: The Benefits are fantastic! The financial benefits with ESPP, 401k, and bonuses are great. Snacks on every floor is a nice perk. The volunteer time off program is a great way to spend a lot of time giving back. The PTO policy offers quite a bit of time off for the first year. The people in the office are very nice and helpful. The workplace is very fun and exciting. It is a fast paced environment where everything changes.
cons: The training program for many positions is limited, which creates a more on-the-job-learning environment. This is fine for some, but others may have issues if they are learning something brand new. Also, I would like to learn more about the products even if you are in a service role versus a sales role.

headline: The greatest company to work for
pros:
very organized teams
great social benefits
career guidance
Great culture
cons: nothing i can think of

headline: Awesome but beware of bad managers as HR doesn't track employee morale or manager sentiment
pros: Fun, dynamic, great people, innovative. Great company and their philanthropic model is amazing. They definitely make it cool to work
cons: Still operating as a start up. Lacking programatic approaches and there is a lack of fiscal responsibility. Another thing noticed is a lot of "punting the ball" as there is no accountability.

headline: Compassionate High Performers
pros:
Tremendous market momentum
Inspired leadership
High performance culture
1/1/1 model includes great charitable matching and 6 days of paid volunteerism per year
cons:
High growth often comes through acquisitions which can be stressful, no matter how good you are at doing them
Getting a little larger and more bureaucratic
Aggressive hiring leading to loss of pure SaaS evangelists (latecomers aren't as passionate about the SaaS model)

headline: Try to get a job with Salesforce - you will not regret
pros:
One company that makes you feel part of their success and make you feel that you are valuable to the company.
I have worked in other large organizations and that bit was missing. There is a ton of opportunities  you can explore and they make you have everything to be successful.
Extremely helpful and seamless onboarding.
You have to deliver though, but if you are taken care of, then I dont think that should be an issue for anyone.
cons: It takes a bit of time to really understand what they are doing, but not really a negative but sometimes could be overwhelming for a new comer ..so just have patience and you will do well.

headline: Senior member of technical staff
pros:
Great culture
Great company
Great team
Treats
Great offices
Pay seemed good
Dreamforce is great
cons:
It is what you make of it
San Francisco location is a downer
Not everyone is on board with the culture

headline: Great company, benefits, flexibility
pros:
The benefits and flexibility of working for salesforce can't be beat. It's an enormous organization, and I work for a smaller subsidiary, so your team and work experience will vary based largely on to whom you report, as always.

The leadership, and Mark benioff in particular, take vocal political stances against anti-LGBT and other discriminatory legislation, which is practically unheard of in the corporate world, but is tremendously valuable to society when a software giant like salesforce takes the lead
cons: cons will always depend on your group, team and manager

headline: Finance Executive Review
pros: Great cutting edge company to work for. CEO is incredibly transparent and cares about the employees. Challenging working environment in that nearly all interactions were with hugely talented peers.Was able to build and expand my function during my tenure there.  Had access to most "C" level executives. Salesforce and its leaders value diversity. Felt I was rewarded by what I achieved versus who I was.  Learned quite a bit and would recommend the company to other executives.
cons: As the company grows it is challenged with losing its "soul". Company "edicts" don't seem to be shared or implemented by all sections of the company. Still quite a bit of "politics" between groups  and individuals which can get in the way of even greater ideas and success. Salesforce risks becoming "ORACLE-ized" with the influx of so many ORACLE veterans.  Daisey-chain decision making is deeply rooted and changing it will be difficult.

headline: Still growting company
pros: Great atmosphere to work. Good compensation and salaries well paid.
cons: Grown up already in some area, and need continuing to find new area.

headline: Lead Sales Engineer
pros: Rapidly expanding company and customers who are really interested in products. Great internal support process and team. Lots of very smart people who are very excited about the company. Continues innovation  in the product. Working here was a great learning opportunity on how tech sales should work.
cons: You are expected to be available 24x7. Internal joke is that company should be called "divorce force". Extremely aggressive and very political sales culture. You must drink the koolaid on the products and the company. Because people are expected to be on the message 100% of the time it often comes across as fake. And most people know that.

headline: Salesforce Review
pros: Salesforce has a fun culture. Most people I've encountered at the company want each other to succeed. The company has a very good paid time off (PTO) and volunteer time off (VTO) plan. It's a good place to work.
cons: It's extremely fast paced. Your expected to be available most of the time, given notice. For instance, it's not uncommon to have calls with teams in other countries at night. I've been on calls that started as late as 10pm EST.

headline: Lead Sales Engineer
pros: Rapidly expanding company and customers who are really interested in products. Great internal support process and team. Lots of very smart people who are very excited about the company. Continues innovation  in the product. Working here was a great learning opportunity on how tech sales should work.
cons: You are expected to be available 24x7. Internal joke is that company should be called "divorce force". Extremely aggressive and very political sales culture. You must drink the koolaid on the products and the company. Because people are expected to be on the message 100% of the time it often comes across as fake. And most people know that.

headline: Salesforce Review
pros: Salesforce has a fun culture. Most people I've encountered at the company want each other to succeed. The company has a very good paid time off (PTO) and volunteer time off (VTO) plan. It's a good place to work.
cons: It's extremely fast paced. Your expected to be available most of the time, given notice. For instance, it's not uncommon to have calls with teams in other countries at night. I've been on calls that started as late as 10pm EST.

headline: hello123
pros: Can learn something exciting and new
cons: Boring hours especially during breaks

headline: Join a great team, work for terrible executives
pros: The character, culture, and quality of the individuals on the development teams at Salesforce are the best you'll ever find, willing to teach and mentor junior engineers to make the most of your potential.
cons: I find the great team culture to be true in spite of rather than because of the fact the leadership is slow to react to a very dynamic and growing company space, and seems to be paralyzed to find or grow new leadership at the pace the company needs to grow. Because of this you have a lot of political jockeying at the top, with little regard for the individuals suffering from low touch leadership. A symptom of this behavior is the fact that the company is extremely top heavy, with half of the "directors" in the company having few to no direct reports under them. Additionally, good luck actually getting an effective interview at Salesforce, as the recruiting is the worst I've ever seen. Again this actually not the fault of the recruiters, but the hiring managers refusal to get out of the weeds and focus on their real job: building good teams.

headline: Supervisor/Manager
pros:
The Salesforce Foundation is amazing.  Employees are urged and given the time away to perform charity work.
Benefits/Salary
Company is truly innovative
cons: Pace.  Culture is slipping from the ExactTarget days. Highly sales driven which makes life on the non sales teams challenging.

headline: Great company and start-up experience
pros: RelateIQ (now SalesforceIQ) has a strong culture and one of the best teams that you'll be able to find. People work hard and also love to hang out at team events, card and board game nights, LAN party nights and so on. Engineers are generally very strong, have lots of autonomy and face little process overhead. The leadership team around Steve Loughlin, Adam Evans and Stephen Ehikian is one to look up to and learn from.
cons: No real cons today, but as Salesforce, a much bigger and more corporate company, slowly but steadily absorbs the former start-up there might come a point where the above Pros can't be upheld anymore.

headline: Great company and people
pros: Awesome benefits, company of people.
cons: you are isolated in your world

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Really good teams and development work. Time to spend on your innovative ideas and work. Lots of benefits and employee centric company.
cons: Promotions take longer and leadership is too dynamic. More competitive salaries with competitors. Teams are too big to be managed.

headline: Great Company
author_position: Senior Member Technical Staff Quality Engineering
pros: Fantastic benefits, great product. Recommend.
cons: Hard to get ahead. Oh well.

headline: Great company, culture and focus on customer success
pros: Very open internal culture. Having worked at Oracle prior I was pleasantly surprised at the level of employee engagement and openness to the company vision and strategy. Mostly Tier 1 people that you work with in Tier 1 facilities and tools. A great place to expand your network and learn how a well run company is run.
cons: Hi growth may mean you will get paired down to a very small sales territory or a very specific job in another function. Make sure you know what your responsibilities and span of control will be going in.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Focus on top priority, leader in foundation, growth and opportunities, market leader, Dreamforce, top talent
cons: Too many layers in decision making leads to people doing things because one of the bosses asks for it rather than because it is the right thing to do.

headline: Summer Internship
pros: Great company. Great team! Highly recommended. The biggest pros about Salesforce is that you get to work on great software and have a work-life balance along with it.
cons: No real cons. The only thing is that it is in San Francisco where the cost of living is through the roof.

headline: vp channels
pros: leader in cloud industry, great customers and partners, very experienced senior management team.
cons: channel conflict on the rise

headline: Great Company and time to focus on employee development.
pros:
-Very focused on success of customers and transforming the way business is done.
-Very very impressive track record and proud to be part of this initiative to give back to our community, globally via 1% model.
cons:
-Employee has to be a new flavor and there is no focus on development of career. 
- Managers are more focused on hiring new skills rather than development of existing skills. 
- Change is the normal SOP, however no recognition or reward to employees who execute the change or Sr Management are awarded.

headline: Senior Account Executive
pros: Innovation, Culture of giving back to local communities
cons: Too much innovation, too quickly, to properly sell and manage existing accounts.

headline: Salesforce
pros: Great benefits, open culture and a strong belief for giving back to others.  On-boarding process was very smooth and everything you need is provided on day one.  Recruiter was on top of everything and followed up consistently along the way to make sure you had the information you needed.
cons: There is a lot to learn and information is pretty spread out.  Once you navigate where the best information is it is a lot easier.

headline: Great place to work
pros: The company cares about its employees. The vision and energy of the CEO have a positive impact throughout the organization. They truly care about their customers.
cons: The company has grown quite a bit so you can feel lost in the shuffle or out of touch sometimes. Would like to see even greater transparency for the product roadmap and plan for the future.

headline: tech areas
pros: Everything is good if you really love data work. I mean, anything related to big data. Benefits are fine
cons: Kind of boring if you stay long. Not so many choices, and not flexible in areas you are interested, so it really depends on your interest.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: It's great working at a company that encourages charitable giving and volunteering. The 1:1:1 model might not seem like much but the way it's embedded into the culture lets us feel good about working, where it's not just all about the bottom line but also doing some good along the way.
cons: Like any other large companies, there's going to be some bureaucratic overhead and siloing going on. While Salesforce does pretty well for a company of its size, it's definitely not a startup anymore.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: very good work life balance
cons: techniques are not that interesting

headline: Join the Revolution!
pros:
•	Amazing corporate culture:
- work hard but have fun doing it
- unbelievable benefits that are constantly increasing
- great work/life balance
 -huge emphasis on giving back to the community 
- insanely smart workforce 
- win as a team and lose as a team mentality
•	Best-in-class products
•	Complete focus on customer success
•	First-rate training and constant support
•	Endless upward mobility opportunities 
•	A meritocracy where employees are handsomely rewarded for hard work
•	You’ll never get bored!
cons:
•	Getting in isn’t easy, the selection process is lengthy and highly competitive
•	On-boarding process takes up to 6 months
•	Constantly evolving company, can be hard to keep up (but there is tons of support)
•	Due to staggering growth, some slight growing pains are evident (but feedback is welcome)
•	Sales cycles are complex and involve numerous players/processes (again, lots of support)

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros:
Very good company to work for.
Loads of responsibilities given and learning every day from them
cons: I don't have anything bad to say in my experience with Salesforce

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Very good pay, good working environment. Most of the co worksers are very friendly.
cons: Sometimes overtime is very pushy. Management is not very clear. Different people might lead you at same time.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Positive work place currently good
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Not what it was
pros: Great product, compensation, & benefits
cons: I work on the Marketing Cloud. Invasion of Oracle folks have brought the Oracle culture.  AE's are treated as commodity, and goals and expectations are constantly being updated with new demands making it difficult to stay focused on brining in new ACV.  Top brass constantly preaches how we're a customer company and how we love our customers, yet we offer no support, training or resources unless they pay through the nose.  Free resources are not good enough to get clients going, and company doesn't really care if they renew or not.

headline: Technical Program Manager (Developer Relations)
author_position: Technical Program Manager | Developer Evangelist Team
pros:
* Worked at Developers Relations Team 
* I loved this company, I still love its innovation, I respect and admire but inside world is little different 

- Cutting edge technologies, culture of innovation push company moving forward in fast pace
- You learn how to market products much more than any other peers in market
- Exciting and positive outlook about company, that keep you motivated
- Great give back culture, not question on CEO Leadership and philanthropic nature that is ingrained in company
cons:
- Its not engineering company, let me clear, this is Sales/Market, they do it very well and they are great at it and they know it very well. 

- Half finished products, over marketed to kill competitors 

- Work at google/facebook, you realize the products they realize are how developers first, and how salesforce products are 'Sales' first 

- Work Life Balance - You better be ready to for it, you get burned out so easily, because of repeated release you are always in deadline and pressure to finish. Upper management in Evangelist Team should be engineers 

Dreamforce  : Life is hell for employees, ready to work late hours, when I say, its mean 1 am in night and back again by 8am  (Though excitement of carnival keep your motivated)

- Salary low comparison to other competitors, you make more as Salesforce lead in other companies than salesforce itself

- Stop politics in upper management, learn from Facebook/Google

- Slow growth in Developer Relations/ Evangelist Team, you work hard, hard and hard and smart speakers takes the credit, you will be give 'bare minimum credit' of what you innovated or created from scratch 

- It is not an engineering company, you won't see real engineers in Facebook/Google for the most, they are innovative but deadline is more important that robust technologies, so clearly yes its not proper engineering company

- Ask this question, how much Salesforce is used inside (Technical Evangelist) team, they know the platform is limited, but go in dreamforce, you see whole different story

- Working both outside and inside Salesforce, I see major flaws in marketing of products and they way they actually are, clients are super pissed because of repeated and constant updates and low backward compatibility, they purchase and are stuck

headline: Great company and only getting better.
pros: Great place to work.  Work life balance is wonderful.  Although I think this depends on your manager and the teams you are apart of.  However, as a standard, this place sets a great example.  I'm fortunate to work with my team.
cons: Fast pace and at times people do not have a realistic understanding of timing for projects.  Which makes you feel like you aren't able to shine at times because it is never delivered fast enough.  This isn't always the case but mostly with T&P teams.

headline: AE
pros: Great great technology and product to sell.  The development team here are off the charts good.  The Sales Engineers are world class.  I love Marc's mission cry and every time I hear Patrick or Keith speak I'm in a fit of joy to go out and help new customers.  High octane and high IQ environment.  Some greats here for sure.
cons:
The leadership here needs to provide management training to VPs.  While the training AE's get is 2nd to none, the direct management and coaching falls extremely short.  For example, 6 months in, I have yet to have any kind of a review or coaching.   

There's also a common thread of jaded sales reps here.  For example, "I took x account almost to the finish line, the fiscal year ended, and someone else got credit for the deal."  This is a systemic problem because I have noticed those reps no longer enter information into Salesforce..what's the point if you'll lose the client next year.  

Team building - really another surprising gap here. I'm sure San Francisco HQ doesn't have this problem.   

Too new to be offended but the above is real.   We get the "best company to work for" but really its the "best product to sell."  Which isn't bad but not great.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
They seem to care
Able to take advantage of many opportunities
Training 
Pay
Benefits
cons: No real cons as far as I'm concerned

headline: Director of Products

cons: Need better access to senior members as a remote employee and better pay scale for those in the Foundation.  More opportunities to present in front of senior leadership

headline: i love it here

headline: It could be better!

Salesforce has a great brand, the product is awesome and HQ culture is amazing.

This is a Sales Company, you will have many trainings and materials to learn the best way to sell.
cons:
Base salary is very low in comparison with others IT companys but totalcomp is agressive If you hit it, and thats why sfdc brazil is a mess, cause quota was not adjusted to HC numbers and market size, so it's impossible to hit it.

All managers and CXOs do not have sfdc culture, so they thing salesforce is any other IT company and don't see all great people they have there.

headline: Impressive!
pros: Forward thinking company that invests in their employees success and gives back to the community. I would recommend Salesforce to anyone.
cons: There are no downsides to this company, it is a forward thinking company that invests in their employees success and gives back to the community. I would recommend Salesforce to anyone.

headline: Great Experience

headline: Tax Intern
pros: Salesforce invests a lot into their employees. They want every member of their team to feel appreciated, excited to come to work, and to have the opportunity to change departments if they do not feel their current role is for them. The employees themselves are, for the most part, intelligent, engaging, and truly excited to work there. It is a great community of people to work with.
cons: In the short time I was there, I did not find any downsides.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Big company security, but startup intensity.  Definitely opportunity if you are a go-getter.  Work with a lot of very smart people.

pros: Salesforce invests a lot into their employees. They want every member of their team to feel appreciated, excited to come to work, and to have the opportunity to change departments if they do not feel their current role is for them. The employees themselves are, for the most part, intelligent, engaging, and truly excited to work there. It is a great community of people to work with.

headline: messy!

headline: Business Analyst
pros: This company truly cares about and invests heavily in its employees. I've never met an unhappy employee! Everyone is extremely supportive of each other's careers. You learn a lot just within your first few months and its very rewarding. The company's philanthropic model is so inspiring, and you feel like you're actually making a difference while still working at a Fortune500.

headline: Sales Engineer

cons: None in my opinion. Salesforce is a great company and good people overall.

headline: Leader in Business
pros: Company is laser focused on customer success, leadership, innovation and giving back.  Despite our size and growth trajectory we remain fast and nimble.  Being part of a high growth company whose mission is in the business of making the world a better place offers a playground of career opportunity and meaningful work.  Our 1:1:1 model is a huge differentiator.  We live and breath giving back in our community.  The passion and energy is contagious.  You can actually feel the energy when you walk into our offices.
cons: nothing.. continue to stay laser focused on big picture and reduce noise associated as we continue on our growth trajectory.

headline: A Lot of Opportunity to Make a Big Impact
pros:
* A lot of opportunity to innovate - fairly good level of empowerment to decide how to do to the work
* Smart, energetic, passionate people
* Flexibility to work from home or the office; great office space, including the option to work from different "campuses" around the area; love the free barista-made coffee
cons:
* Would like to see more accountability for being great managers
* Be great to have a real gym in our building (do get a fitness studio (no equipment) and gym discounts)
* Better, healthier, more snack and lunch options, including a true cafe

headline: Great place to work at
pros: Great company outlook and culture
cons: Limited professional growth opportunity and lots of red tape

headline: Great company- if a bit corporate
pros: Salesforce runs like a well oiled machine, which can be refreshing if you're coming from start-up chaos. They give you lots of options and support for career development/advancement. Work/life balance is good, and benefits are comprehensive.
cons: This is a big company that focuses mostly on B2B tech, so it can feel very corporate. Vibe depends on which division you're in.

headline: Interview Process
pros: There's free coffee and snacks.
cons: Interview process is not reasonable.

headline: Great Company
pros: Awesome culture. Fast Growth
cons: n/a. no cons from me

headline: AE Role

headline: Great Sales training
pros: Great sales training and was taught a lot about how to sell. Working at Salesforce.com makes it SUPER easy to find a job once you want to leave. Head hunters will call you a lot.
cons: Awful culture. "Build your brand" is a sentence that is being thrown around constantly. It effectively means "strategically suck up".

headline: Great culture, rapid pace of innovation
pros:
- rapid growth/opportunities
- management was very supportive of crazy ideas
- constant learning from smart people all around you
- annual dreamforce event was a blast - customers REALLY love SFDC products/services
cons:
- a little HQ centric - many decisions made in SFO that didn't really need to be
- responsibilities change so frequently (as a result of rapid growth) that it is hard to master them before new ones are added

headline: Highly recommend
pros: Employees are treated as the #1 stakeholder and valued greatly. Theres a  huge emphasis on career growth and employee services. There is a high emphasis on delivering results, but also good work life balance. Management is approachable and employees are passionate about what they do and are generally happy to be there.
cons: Headcount is growing rapidly and at times feels like youre losing the community feel the company is known for. Could be difficult to maintain company culture.

headline: Amazing Company
pros: Innovative, fast paced, great fun culture that cares about employees
cons: Need to improve work/life balance

headline: From riches to rags
pros:
Great company 3 years ago. Then it tripled and went to the wolves. 

Work life balance is good. If you wanna sit and grow at a steady pace then it's great. Don't expect too many merit based incentives. 

Some free lunches. Easy to switch teams parallely. Vertical movement is easier for management. Horizontal movement is extremely scrutinized (they would rather hire inexperienced interns than in-house and train someone for a position)

Company stocks are great. Bonuses are ok. Company has still a lot of room to grow which is great for its workers.
cons:
If you are the kind of person who thrives on appearance and taking credit for others work OR if you're a manager. Then this is the place for you. Work is not connected to pay. The impression of work is. 

Manager are pretty much guaranteed promotions every year if they don't distribute their budget on promoting their hires. I've known developer who've left because of this and also conscientious managers who were tired of playing the devil. 

Tripled in size in 3 years and the culture is no more. Now it's a hodgepodge of Microsoft and oracle.

headline: Data Engineer

Great employee perks
Flexible work times
Great location

headline: Great and Innovative!

(Less than 1% of applicants receive employment offers) -Strong community environment: Salesforce has been able to build a corporate family unlike any company I've been a part of before.

They will tell you every one loves them but adoption of the product is low.
I gladly took a pay cut to get out of the company

cons: The offices are located in sandyford which is quite far from the city centre, the commute from the city centre takes around 30 minutes using the free exective bus transfers.

headline: Great for the name and starting experience....look out for the Kool-Aid
pros:
- Salesforce has become the gold standard for B2B tech these days. No, recruiters won't be running to you, but you can feel "validated" as a sales person in the tech space after working there
- The training for an entry level tech sales person is fantastic. They teach you how to approach opportunities/ accounts and push you to master these skills
cons:
- The Kool-Aid. You must LOVE the product, LOVE your team, LOVE your managers, LOVE the process. Oh, and you better LOVE going to happy hours, clubs and team outings with your coworkers.
- Because of the terrible work/life balance, brown-nosing to get ahead is very very prevalent. There's a huge amount of gossip and "buy in" that's required. It's not a workplace for individuals, it's a workplace for THEIR individual.

headline: Hard-core, cold-calling, koolaid-drinking environment
pros: Good Healthcare, cheap movie tickets, paid to volunteer a few days a year.
cons:
Base pay will be lower than their competitors. You'll be expected to work long hours, a lot of overtime and practically live there at the end of each month and quarter. Hard to obtain quotas, but you'll get no sympathy if you speak up or ask for support. 
It's a machine...a hard-core, cold-calling environment. Your phone WONT ring just because they're "Salesforce", despite what they'll feed you in your interview. 
If you're headed there...prepare for the stress and long nights!

headline: Amazing people & culture

* Volunteering is encouraged.
cons: * Not the smartest of folks on some of the teams.

cons:

headline: Beware of micro-managers and ass-kissing execs
pros: Decent pay, good benefits, flexible telecommuting policy, nice co-workers
cons: Transitioning from start-up to big corporation, execs are young and eager to please parent company in Cali by kissing up while transferring the stress to employees. Zero tolerance for mistakes but not giving any warning sign until the last minute before they fire you. Due to poor location excellent employees are few and far between, so mediocre but ass-kissing people get to stay. Managers are all great players of politics. Employees don't dare to speak their mind just to keep their jobs in the "best" company of the area.  Mid-level people managers have no clue in managing so resort to micromanagement. Typical "boys club" culture with no advancement opportunity for female. Only those who play well with their managers and drink the Salesforce cool-aid will thrive. The V2MOM is a joke as performance review has nothing to do with it, meaning delivering results doesn't mean you are good enough. Fear of mistakes and risk averse mindset is suffocating the humanity and innovation this company once had.

Extremely good benefits and pay, well above the market average. Make sure to take up the pension! ;)

headline: Chill place but no "engineering excellence"
pros: The best thing about working here is that it's relatively relaxing as the company is doing well. The company is generous about your hours and let's you do things like volunteer your time.
cons: That being said, seriously, most people that work here are hacks and idiots. It's 2015 and they're building software like it's still 1998. Don't expect to come here and learn anything other than how to pass the hot potato. You'll spend 95% of your time doing "keep the lights on" work, fixing messes that were created 5+ years ago but people were to dumb to notice. Those people who made those messes are no in key, influential positions within the company, where their questionable decision making has maximum impact to shoot themselves in the foot.
